Sir:-

I beg to transmit herewith, vouchers Nos.3553 and 3554 amounting altogether to £28.00 for labor painting and cleaning walls and floor of class-room of Kitkatla Indian Day School. The building being old and the floor much the worse for wear, it was considered advisable to have this work done during the summer vacation.

The painting has placed the interior of the school in a more sanitary condition and it will be easier to keep the floor clean during the coming winter months. This is the first time the floor has been painted for some years and the undertaking required more paint and labor. I would recommend payment of the accounts.

Your obedient servant,

WEC, JJ
Indian Agent

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

I have the honor to transmit herewith, Vouchers Nos.5159 and 5160 attached to which are accounts received from the Gordon Hardware Co. and the Thompson Hardware Co. of Prince Rupert for spades supplied for the Kitkatla Indian Village.

In explanation I would state, the Kitkatla Indians have been engaged in carrying out village street improvements and made request for assistance in the way of spades as they had no money with which to buy these implements. As the work in which they were engaged was a deserving one, and in which I think they should be encouraged, assistance was given, and I would recommend that the accounts be paid.

Your obedient servant,

WEC JJ

Indian Affairs. (RG. 10, Volume 6397, File 821-5, part 1)
Ottawa, August 12, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, regarding the equipment and repairs required at the Kitkatla Indian Day School. It is noted that the present stove is unfit for further use.

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of a new stove of a type that would be satisfactory. You may also purchase and supply the quantity of stove pipe and elbows required. Regarding the repairs, you may arrange for the adjustments required to the windows and to have new railings installed on the approach to the school toilets, also a new plank walk to school entrance. The total cost of the stove and repairs, including labour and freight, should be kept within your estimate viz., $76. Any repairs carried out should, if possible, be performed by Indians.

After the above purchases and repairs have been completed, you should forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B.C.
Sir:-

I beg to state that the following repairs and improvements are needed for the Kitkatla Indian Day School which, if approved, I shall be glad to receive the necessary authority to have done.

1 new stove, 6 lengths stovepipe, 1 elbow, & windows to be adjusted.................. 50.00

New railings on approach to school toilets 3.00

New plank walk to school entrance, length-20 ft x 3 ft. 5.00

Labor 12.00

Freight & handling charges, PR. to Kitkatla $6.00

$76.00

A new stove is needed for this school as the present one which has been in use for many years will not last out the coming winter, and is not worth repairing.

The railing on the approach to the school toilets is necessary as a safeguard, the approach being some seven feet from the ground. On account of the fact that all material must be shipped from Prince Rupert to Kitkatla by gasboat the cost of transportation and handling adds considerably to the expense.

A requisition for school material is also enclosed and I shall be glad if these are sent as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

WEC, JJ

Indian Agent

Ottawa, November 19, 1931.

Sir:

Mr. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia, who recently inspected the Kitkatla Indian Day School, draws attention to the condition of the toilets, which he states are in a filthy state. He recommends that the seats be removed, cleaned and replanned, as he does not think ordinary scrubbing will be sufficient. He also states that the doors of the toilets should be repaired and locks fitted, and the doors kept locked, except when school is in session.

I have to request that you will arrange as soon as possible to have these toilets thoroughly cleaned and placed in a good, sanitary condition, and locks installed on the doors, the keys to which should be placed under the charge of the teacher, who should see that these toilets are kept locked, as stated above. - 200 feet lumber @ $25.00 = 7.50
- nails = 1.00
- labor = 10.00
- freight charges to Kitkatla = 5.00

$29.90

Application has also been made by the school teacher Mr. Shearman for calsimine and varnish to renovate the interior of the teacher's residence. The work will be carried out by himself. The following material will be required:

- Calsimine 6 packages @ 75¢ = 6.00
- Varnish 1 gallon @ $6.00 = 6.00
- Paint brushes 2 @ 75¢ = 1.50

$13.50

In view of the fact that the painting of the interior walls, ceilings and doors of the teacher's residence was not completed at the time the house was put up three years ago, the addition of a little paint to renovate the rooms would add considerably to the comfort of the teacher and his family.

I would recommend that the repairs to the toilet and painting of the interior of the teacher's residence be carried out if funds are available.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:-

RE: Repairs Kitkatla Day School.

I wish to draw the attention of the Department to the need of repairs for the above named school.

The building is over 25 years old and is badly in need of repairs. When the building was first put up, the rear end was allowed to rest on the ground with the result that the sills are rotted and should be replaced, as the building is settling. It will be necessary to dig away part of the bank on which the end of the school rests in order to give free ventilation. The roof needs repairing, and, also new panes for the windows.

The entire cost of repairing the foundation, including labour, material and transportation, will be approximately $150.00 as follows:

| Item                          | Cost   |
|-------------------------------|--------|
| Labour                        | $65.00 |
| Material (Lumber, nails, cedar posts, etc.) | $60.00 |
| Transportation from Prince Rupert to Kitkatla | $25.00 |

Total: $150.00

The outside of the building should be painted at a cost of $25.00.

3 gallons of paint @ $5.00 = $15.00
Labour = $10.00

Total: $25.00
I would recommend that this necessary work be carried out as soon as possible, and shall be glad to hear from the Department in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Your file 15/8/5614

I submit herein a report on Kitkatla Indian Day School as requested in your letter of May 10.

The building was erected about 30 years ago and is in an unsuitable locality, being among the Indian houses and too near the beach. It does not now present a very good appearance as the roof is covered with lichen, which it would not be advisable to move as leaks may develop. The outside walls are weather worn and a number of boards are missing around the base. Three of the foundation posts need renewing. The inside walls are dark and dingy.

If it is the intention of the Department to build a new school in the near future, I recommend that only the minimum and necessary repairs be made this year, which are as follows:

Repairs to windows.
- 10 panes glass 14 x 22 $8.00
- 5 lbs. putty .50
- putty knife .35
- labour (approx.) $8.00

Repairs to ridgeboard.
- 100 ft. lumber 1 x 6 4.00
- labour 2.00

Repairs to foundation.
- 3 posts including labour 5.00

Repairs to toilets.
- 12 pcs. lumber 6"x1"x12" 3.00
- 4 lbs nails .30
- labour erecting partition 4.00

Freight on material. 5.00

$40.15
If, however, it is foreseen that a new school is not likely to be built for a number of years, extensive repairs should be made next year. This would mean reshingling the roof, painting the walls inside and out and clearing up the surroundings at an approximate cost of $400.00. I will place such an item in the estimates for 1941-42.

Yours faithfully,

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Reporting on his inspection of the Kitkatla Indian Day School on the 9th ultimo Inspector Barry writes as follows:

"School is a very old building which requires much work done on it, foundations etc. Windows are now out of plumb. Glass broken in eight places. Windows boarded up in places to keep out wind, can not be opened. Indian Agent will no doubt do what he can to improve conditions till a new school can be erected on a better site. S No. 4 and S No. 3 single desks are most urgently needed, also new heater to burn coal."

From previous reports received from you this Branch is aware that the Kitkatla School is in bad condition. Due to present conditions it was impossible to obtain the funds required for the erection of a new school. However, it is possible that a reasonable expenditure during the coming summer would place this building in a habitable condition for another year. In this connection I may say that an amount of $300.00 was provided in the current year's appropriation for minor repairs and improvements required at all the day schools in the Skeena Agency. Please let me know what portion of this amount you would recommend be expended at Kitkatla.

Yours truly,

Mr. J. Gillett,
Indian Agent,

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver.

Re voucher no. 109 attached, in favor of Silversides Bros. of this city, this glass was bought to effect repairs following a fire at the teacherage at Kitkatla Indian Day School on January 17th. The teacher, Mrs. Grace Vickers, lit a candle in the morning and unfortunately placed it on a shelf near a window. A gale was in process and blew the candle over and set fire to the baby's bed. The mother heard the crackling of flames, but before the fire could be put out considerable damage was done to windows and interior.

I ordered new glass on the 25th and sent it on a company packer but in a violent storm the crate was knocked over, the glass all smashed, hence the duplication of order, which is regretted.

The account is recommended for payment.

F. Earl Anfield,

July 2nd, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B. C., Vancouver.
Re: Kitkatla Indian Day School, Dolphin Island, B. C.

The Department in a letter dated May 15, file 168-18-5, has written requesting a full report on this School, together with definite recommendations as to whether or not alternative or additional accommodation can be secured on a rental basis to take care of the educational needs of the village of Kitkatla, total population 385, with an estimated school population this fall of 84 children of school age. Of this number, nine children are in Residential Schools leaving 75 to consider as the Day School population for the academic year 1946-47.

A complete inspection of this village Day School was made on June 25th, in company with the Bishop of the Diocese, Rt. Rev. J. B. Gibson, D.D.; the Chief Councillor, Mr. Mathew Hill, and representative Councilmen and other Indians of the village.

The average attendance at this Indian Day School for the last three academic years is as follows:

Year ending June 30th, 1946 - 36
Year ending June 30th, 1945 - 27
Year ending June 30th, 1944 - 27.

PRESENT SCHOOL FACILITIES:

Building, frame, inside dimensions - 22' x 34', walls 10' high. Inside walls and ceilings, dark brown in colour.
Floors - poor. Foundations were checked and found in fair condition.
Windows - thirteen - 4 light on both sides and one end of room.

Heating - MacClary #45 coal stove - totally inadequate.
Blackboards - 12 feet of 3 ft. hyloplate, almost worn through.
Desks - 11 old fashioned double desks, largely worn out, several unusable.
   15 single desks, 7 size 4; 8 size 3; old type in bad condition.
   2 wooden benches broken.
Chimney - 8 inch tile bracket - cracked and unsafe.
Cupboards - none to speak of, supplies are kept in orange boxes.
Teacher's desk - in fair condition.

I desire to refer to your letter of May 4, addressed to the Supervisor of Family Allowances, with reference to the condition of the Kitkatla School.

Owing to conditions existing at the present time, I regret very much that I cannot see any prospect of erecting a new school at Kitkatla during the current calendar year. However, the necessity for such a building has been noted and we will endeavour to obtain funds for its erection in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1947-48.

In the meantime we are prepared to spend a reasonable amount in repairing the present building so as to make it as habitable as possible. If there is any building at Kitkatla that we could rent, temporarily, for school purposes, we would be willing to do so.

Please let me hear from you further regarding the above suggestions.

Philip Phelan,

The Kitkatla school plant and general condition are bad. Seventy children are enrolled in a building that should be torn down. At best it should not seat more than 25; thirty to forty are jammed in at a session. The floors are in a dangerous condition and the walls and ceiling very poor. In cold weather the building is damp and drafty and it is almost impossible to heat the building, which is in charge of one teacher. Parents have refused to allow children to attend in bad weather, attendance being in their stated opinion a risk to the children's health. In this statement, I am compelled to concur.

It is urgent that this school be replaced with a modern two class-room building, including teachersage, and provision for a dispensary and Field Matron's quarters.

August 30th, 1947

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

RE: Kitkatla School

This school is very overcrowded and in addition is very old and extremely dilapidated. Estimates for 1947-48 included items for a new school. These have been repeated for the fiscal year 1948-49. There is a need for at least a two roomed and possibly three roomed school for this village. To date one teacher, Mrs. Nellie Campbell, has been appointed for this school. She arrives in Prince Rupert on August 30th and arrangements are being made to take her to Kitkatla next week.

In Kitkatla there is a real need for a medical dispensary and nursing station, with quarters for a nurse or village matron. Items to cover this construction have been placed in the current medical estimates. The Indian Health Services have authorized a radio phone installation for this village. It is obviously impossible to get materials for a new school this fall and consideration is requested to the following plan, which may solve the temporary school needs of this village.

(1) There is available at Group 4, ex R.C.A.F. Camp, Prince Rupert, a loxstave building 76 x 24 x 10. Specifications of this building are attached here-with. The prices of same, as is, where is, being $1,050.00

(2) I have inspected this building very carefully inside and out and have secured the following bids on the dismantling and removal of same. The cost of taking down and rebuilding at Kitkatla - $800.00; cost of transporting material to scow, loading same and transporting to Kitkatla and unloading there approximately - $1,450.00, though the outfits contacted are unable to give a firm bid at this time, as it is almost impossible to know exactly how long the scows may have to remain on charter.
Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

Page 2.

(3) The cost of new equipment including stoves, cupboards, blackboards and a coat of paint in the interior will cost approximately $500.00. To this should be added $200.00 for a Barrett roof.

The total cost of putting this building into operation as a two roomed school at Kitkatla should not exceed $4,000.00. The building is only three years old, it cost the Government $7,000.00 to erect and the loss on demolition of this type of building should not exceed 4%. Attached please find two snaps of the building in question. Contractors demolishing Group 4 agree to give us ten days in which to accept or reject this building. It is considered that this would be a good buy from every point of view. The building has a life expectancy of at least twenty years and it would be readily convertible to a nursing station, combined with quarters for field matron and two teachers, should the Department later decide to build a modern school at this village. It should be remembered in considering the urgency of the needs at Kitkatla that during the past two years only senior grade children have been able to go to school in this village. It was suggested last year that the Church Army Hall be converted for temporary use as a class room. This is no longer possible, as last winter storms weakened this building to the place where it is now propped up with poles and would be unsafe for a school.

Consideration of the purchase and re-erection of this building #12 is recommended. If the plan is not feasible for financial reasons, would you please advise at once so that the contractors may be given an opportunity to dispose of it forthwith.

MEMORANDUM.

To: The Indian Commissioner

From: Inspector of Indian Schools.

I refer to Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letter dated August 30th, 1947, in which he proposes the purchase of a building of logstave construction at Prince Rupert for use at Kitkatla for school purposes. There has been considerable correspondence on the need for further accommodation at the point, and in February of this year, when I visited the school, I noted that it was impossible to accommodate all of the pupils, the beginners and Grade I pupils being excluded. It seems improbable that this need can be met by ordinary methods for some time, and the use of this building will relieve the situation for a considerable period. In a report dated July 2nd, 1946, Mr. Anfield stated that there were 75 children of school age who should be accommodated in the Day School in the 1946-47 academic year. He also stated in the same report that the foundation of the present school was in fair condition. This building could be used to accommodate a third class if necessary.

Mr. J.M. Wardle, Director of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, in a report dated November 10th, 1946, on similar buildings at the Port Hardy Camp, stated that it was practical to transport these buildings within a radius of sixty miles. The distance from Prince Rupert to Kitkatla is well within this limit.

The estimate of $4000. for this work seems to be rather small, but the use of the building would represent a considerable saving over new construction, which, under the present condition of shortages, is impossible.

Although no funds have been allocated for this work, it might be possible to divert some of the money intended for the construction of the new school at Hazelton, which cannot be undertaken this year.

I recommend that the purchase of this building be authorised subject to Mr. Anfield securing the services of a contractor to dismantle, transport and re-erect the building at Kitkatla.
It is also suggested that Mr. Anfield secure the release from the Band of a suitable site for the location of this building at Kitkatla.

R.F. Davey
Inspector of Indian Schools.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,

We have for acknowledgment your letter of September 16th enclosing memorandum from the Surveys and Engineering Branch with reference to utilizing certain buildings at the Port Hardy Military Camp.

We also received your letter of September 4th recommending an expenditure of $4,050 in order to purchase a loxstave building and move same to the Kitkatla Reserve for school purposes.

In our letter of July 10th you were advised that an amount of $26,000 had been allotted for utilization of the buildings at the Port Hardy Camp and at that time we forwarded to you a copy of our memorandum of June 30th with reference to the schools that we were informed could be erected from the materials salvaged from Port Hardy. Attached is a statement indicating the situation as we see it now.

You will note that we have actually allotted an amount of $47,500, and in view of the increased cost at Alert Bay over the amount estimated, we are inclined to feel that the estimated expenditure at the other proposed schools will be over the original estimate.

With the above in mind we have hesitated authorizing the purchase and moving of the loxstave building.

It is possible that you do not propose to build all the buildings mentioned in the attached statement. If so, and if there is an amount of $4,050 available from the total mentioned on our statement, we have no objection to you proceeding with the Kitkatla project.
The point to be kept in mind is that the total expenditure that we can allow for the erection of new day schools in British Columbia during the current fiscal year is $47,500.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Kitkatla Indian Day School,
Keena Indian Agency, B.C.

The Kitkatla school is in very bad condition and we have received a report from Indian Commissioner MacKay suggesting that the following action be taken:

(1) The purchase of a locustave building 76x24x10 from the K.C.A.R. camp at Prince Rupert $1,200.

(2) Removing building from present site, shipping and re-erection by Northwest Construction Company $2,600.

(3) Purchase of desks, blackboards and other equipment and miscellaneous expenses $466.

Total expenditure - - - $4,266.

Owing to the fact that we have not been able to erect other Indian day schools in British Columbia this year, funds to the above amount are available in the current year's appropriation.

I would, therefore, appreciate it if you would approve Indian Commissioner MacKay's recommendation to use the amount mentioned above in order to provide a proper school on the Kitkatla Reserve.

Director.
Indian Affairs branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of October 4th and correspondence from Mr. Indian Agent Anfield in connection with the proposed purchase and re-erection of a logstave building for school purposes at the Kitkatla reserve, Mr. Anfield has now secured firm bids from Messrs. Spies and Mackling and North-West Construction Company covering purchase of the building and its removal and reconstruction at Kitkatla.

The Agent's letter of October 15th and enclosures referred to therein are attached hereto for your information. It is regretted that the proposal has now become somewhat confused in that the Agent's original submission was for the purchase, removal and reconstruction of a building to provide two classrooms, whereas the plan prepared by North-West Construction Co., submitted herewith, shows one classroom with living quarters, which, in my opinion, are unnecessary as we already have accommodation for the teachers at Kitkatla. I am today writing to Mr. Anfield for clarification of the proposal and am prepared to recommend approval of the project if the construction of the logstave building is such that it can be converted to provide two classrooms.

With regard to the question of funds, and referring to the list submitted with Mr. Neary's letter above-referred to it is not anticipated that we will be able to take advantage of the funds provided for school construction at
Page 2.

At Hazelton this year, nor does it appear that construction at Seabird Island will be proceeded with unless a contract can be let.

Under the circumstances it is reasonable to suppose that use of $8,000 of the $7,500 allotted to the Province for the construction of a school at Kitkatla will not interfere with construction which we would otherwise be able to carry out.

I should appreciate therefore authority for Mr. Anfield to proceed with his proposal on the understanding that the cost will not exceed the amount mentioned in his letter of October 15th, namely $4,266.00 and that the building will provide two classrooms.

A reply by airmail would be appreciated.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

This account is in order for payment, with the following explanations:

An item of $80.00 was included in the estimate for purchase of used insulation for this building. When we came to get it, the insulation had been sold and rather than delay the job I instructed the North West Construction Company to buy it and proceed. This was done at a cost of $390.00. To help meet the cost of this material I arranged for Indians to tow the scowload of material for the building to Kitkatla and the North West Company allowed a credit of $200.00 for this service. This leaves a sum of $190.00, which is chargeable to the total Vote of $4,266.00 for this school. I intend to debit the account of Spies and Mackling for part of this sum as they agreed to see that the used insulation was available.

I went over this building at Kitkatla yesterday and having in mind the difficulties of construction, believe that we have a strong and warm building which will fully meet the needs of the school for some time to come. I arranged for the moving of desks and equipment into the new building in which we have put a temporary stove to dry it out. The blackboard and a new stove will be shipped out as soon as present stormy weather abates. I would anticipate that school could start by the end of January next. Would you ask the Department to forward cheque to North West Construction Co., by air mail.

I also feel that Messrs. We are in a position to take a firm stand insofar as Messrs. Spies and Mackling are concerned as the building supplied was not in accordance with their tender, being 15 feet short and not a standard lorstave. It would not be unreasonable to require Spies and Mackling to reduce the amount of their bid to us by $741.67, being the cost of additional materials supplied by the Construction Company, and the difference between the cost of second hand insulation material and new material, $310.00. Re: Kitkatla Indian Day School

We have had considerable correspondence with Superintendent Anfield regarding the above-mentioned school building, half of which apparently was occupied by the Indian Health Services nurse last year, school being conducted in the other half of the building and the old classroom building. Although Mr. Anfield suggested that the arrangement with regard to classroom accommodation should be continued this year and the half of the building occupied by the Indian Health Services converted for use as a teachers' office did not agree with the proposal in view of his comments on many previous occasions with regard to the condition of the old classroom.

It has been decided that it would be preferable to complete this building which was constructed last year at a cost of $4266.00 for use as two classrooms and to carry out minor repairs to the United Church Mission House to accommodate the teachers. Superintendent Anfield's letter of August 9th in this connection is enclosed and I would recommend the Department endeavour to make funds to the extent of $960.54 available and that $601.00 of this amount be forwarded to Mr. Anfield to meet labour costs. While this is quite a large expenditure we will, following completion of the work, have a satisfactory two room school for approximately $5100.00.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

You will recall that last year we moved and re-erected a loxstave building formerly used by the Army, at the Kitkatla Indian Reserve.

Last year we opened one class room in this building and have successfully conducted school during the last winter.

We would now like to open a second class room, to paint the exterior of the building and to clear a playground around the building. We have obtained the following summary of expenditure from our Indian Superintendent, Mr. Anfield, at Prince Rupert:

Res: Kitkatla Indian Day School

Attached please find 37A and bids on material required for repairs to the Kitkatla Indian Day School in the ensuing fiscal year. These are submitted in compliance with a circular from the Department asking for lists of material required for school repairs as early as possible in the fiscal year.

The Kitkatla School requires a coal storage shed. Up until now we have tried to keep the coal and fuel for this school underneath the building but it is an unsatisfactory system and a proper shed under lock and key is essential.

It is also necessary to carry out considerable repairs on the school toilets, which suffered severely under the heavy gales of the past winter.

Purchase of this material is recommended and an accountable advance for $150.00 for labour requested.

Sir:

I beg to confirm my telegram of even date as follows—

"Kindly authorize purchase by tender kitchen and livingroom stoves six common chairs, eleven window blinds and linoleum for teachers residence Kitkatla stop Approximate cost two hundred and fifty dollars stop Kindly wire if approved as wanted immediately."

Having recently returned from Kitkatla Indian village, I was informed by the foreman in charge of construction of the teacher's residence that it will cost a further £250.00 before the house is completed and ready for occupation. The extra expenses are incurred for the following items—

Finishing new building 100.00
Pulling down old missionhouse 50.00
New wood and coal shed 40.00
Toilet 30.00
Water tank 30.00
Box drains 10.00 £250.00

The building appears to be very satisfactory and has been well put up. All the outside doors and window facings etc., have received one coat of paint to protect them from the weather. I would recommend that the whole building be given another coat of paint next summer when weather conditions are better.

As far as the old mission house is concerned, the building is very old, and no use could be made of the windows or doors. The house must be over thirty years old. The best part of the old
lumber will be used in the erection of the coal shed, construction of box drains, and plank walks around the building.

It will also be necessary to partly furnish the new building, and in this connection I would recommend the purchase of the following, as per my wire to the Department.

1 cookstove, McClary's Regina $60.00
1 heater for living room, McClary's $30.00
12 window blinds @ $1.25 $15.75
6 kitchen chairs at $1.75 $10.50
62 sq.yds of linoleum for liv.room $33.00
Lino for kitchen & dispensary @ $1.50 per sq.yd.
2 lin.squares for bedrooms @ $16.00 $32.00
Freight to Kitkatla $10.75 $250.00

The prices quoted are the lowest obtainable in Prince Rupert consistent with quality and service.

Your obedient servant,

W.B.C., JJ Indian Agent

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to the erection of a teacher's residence at Kitkatla, for which authority has already been granted you to have this work carried out.

In this connection it is noted that the only available site for this house requires clearing and that you recommend that a small bedroom be added to the original plan to provide accommodation for the teacher's family. The Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding the sum of approximately $500 to cover the cost of this additional room and the clearing of the ground, which will make a total of approximately $2,800 for the construction of the building and clearing of the land, and the Department will be pleased if a saving in this amount can be effected. You will be forwarded under separate cover accountable cheque No. 1759 for $1,000 to pay the cost of the labour employed on this work, and this should be accounted for by time sheets, in duplicate, covering the amount paid by you from this advance to the individual labourers employed.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Prince Rupert,
B.C.
Sir:—

With further reference to the erection of a teacher's residence at Kitkatla, for which authority has been given by the Department, I beg to state that on further consideration of the plans, copy of which was forwarded to the Department, I beg to recommend the addition of another small bedroom for the accommodation of the teacher's two children, which is very necessary.

The only available site for the house will need clearing and I think an extra $500.00 will cover both cost of additional room and clearing of ground.

The plan and estimate submitted to the Department had been prepared by Mr. J. Mitchell of Prince Rupert, who superintended the erection of the Massett Bay School in 1923 and had also carried out repairs to the school building at Kitkatla two years ago and therefore is well acquainted with conditions at that place. I will however, interview Mr. W.J. Greer as requested, with regard to the building of the residence.

To expedite matters I shall be glad to receive an advance of $1,000.00 so that work may be put in hand at the earliest opportunity.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

"Reference your telegram you may purchase after securing prices from suitable sources equipment for teacher's residence Kitkatla School. Do not exceed your estimate."

After you have made purchase of the furnishings as mentioned in your letter to the amount authorized above, you should forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred. Regarding your recommendation that this building be given another coat of paint next summer, I have to say that you should draw this matter to the attention of the Department next spring, stating, at that time, the approximate cost of material and labour in having the work recommended by you carried out.

Sir:

I have the honor to transmit herewith, Returns of Labor in connection with the construction of the teacher's residence at Kitkatla Indian reserve. Vouchers Nos. 3829 and 3840 with accounts attached for blue prints and incidental expenses are also enclosed. Accounts for material were forwarded under cover of my letter dated January 10th.

As will be seen from the statement attached, the building has cost $3,407.97, being $157.97 in excess of the authorized appropriation. Unfortunately, this could not be avoided owing to unforeseen expenses and delays caused by continued bad weather, and the fact that the building was put up by day labor.

The appropriation having already been exceeded, the painting of the building and bathroom fixtures have been deferred until funds are available. I would recommend that this work be done during the coming summer, if satisfactory to the Department.

The $250.00 authorized for stoves, linoleum etc. was expended and proper vouchers will be forwarded. The house has been well constructed, and it is satisfactory to know the work is now completed as it entailed much time and trouble.

Indian labor was employed as much as possible. One copy of Mr. Scott's return of labor is enclosed for the Department's information, and I shall be glad to receive the amount due to him for wages as shown thereon— if possible by wire to the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Prince Rupert.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 5th instant in connection with a voucher for electricity supplied to the teacher's residence at the Kitkatla Day School.

As I pointed out in my letter of the 7th ultimo it is not our practice to install electricity in any Indian day school nor in any teacher's residence. You will remember that in a letter dated July 31, 1939, you submitted an account for wiring this building. No authority had been given for this expenditure although the account was paid.

I note that the yearly charge is $10.10 and from January 1, 1941, this Department will only allow an amount of $6.00 yearly for electricity for this residence. This is the same amount as was previously expended in the purchase of coaloil.

At the present time we can only consider payment of the balance of $10.00 for installation and the charge of $10.10 for lighting during the year 1940.

The account for the year 1941 should be submitted at the end of December and, as stated above, this Branch will only allow $6.00. The balance will have to be paid by the teacher.

Yours truly,

Mr. J. Gillett,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B.C.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter No. 168-18-8 of April 7th requesting more detail regarding charges for electricity supplied to the teacher's residence at Kitkatla, I wish to state that the first charge on the bill is $10.00. This is the balance due on the Council's charge of $25.00 for labor and material for conveying the current from the main line to the house. The material consisted of wire, poles, insulation, etc. Fifteen dollars of the stated fee was paid by the former teacher's personal funds.

Electricity is not supplied to the school but to the teacher's dwelling, property of the Department, and is a separate building some distance from the school.

Previous to this the Department provided light for the teacher by supplying coal oil which amounted approximately $9.00 yearly.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letter of October 27th in connection with the proposed expenditure of $44.70 for repairs to the Kitkatla Indian Day School teachers' house.

This building is the property of the Anglican Church, but, inasmuch as we have paid no rent for it during the years it has been used as a teachers' house, it is recommended that the expenditure requested be authorized. I may say I have discussed this matter with Mr. Anfield, who has assured me that we may have occupancy of the building during the balance of the present academic year at least, as it is not anticipated that the church will be sending a missionary to Kitkatla.

D. H. MacKay
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Sir,

OTTAWA.

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter, dated the 12th ultimo, referring to my report on the Kitsegukla Indian Day School for last October, which shows that the attendance is still very small owing to the fact that a number of the Indians have not yet removed from the old village to the new.

Thereby am I requested to state what progress is being made as this attendance has been very small for about two years.

In reply thereto, I beg to state that about the middle of that month (October) several families began to move to the new village. This will give that place the number of children, of school age, of 13 instead of 6 as heretofore; and the indications are favourable that that number will be augmented by more in the near future. The process of taking up the new settlement has been much slower than I, at first, anticipated, but hope that the long patience will be rewarded in this respect.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir,

With reference to Departmental letters, dated the 26th of September, last, and the 12th ultimo, regarding to the removal of the Indians from the Old to the New Kitsegukla village, with the request of my report thereupon, I have the honour to state the following in connection therewith,

to wit:-

For the last 17 years have I incessantly been working on finding ways and means whereupon to effect this purpose, but with very poor results, though one family, since the receipt of the former cited letter, has been making that move.

Though for nearly a quarter of a century among these people, I have not early enough made use of the experience that instead of coaxing, had I made the dictum:-

"You must not get upon the New Kitsegukla Reserve, it is forbidden ground," the result would have been as by magic in the perverse order, and would have had them crawling there over night. This can be instanced in the case of Andimaul becoming established. There, about 14 years ago I discouraged the Indians all I could. So soon as they heard of my leaving for a visit to Fort St. James, the people of Old Kitsegukla took down as many as a dozen houses, and rafted them thither, even at night, and Andimaul had become, with others of Kitwanga and Kitwankool joining, a fixture upon my return. I incline to the opinion that upon garden produce becoming more of steady demand, the worthless land about the old village will in the near future become, in toto, exchanged for the fertile soil of the new settlement.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

I am sending you the last quarter report.

I hope that it will be all right.

Last year I had six girls, but now I have only four girls and two boys. The two girls I had last year are here again and I am glad to say that they have come much better than how they were before.

The boys are doing well too. They are taught the outside work by my husband and the boys. They are taught to fix wood up nicely and to get the kindling ready for use at any time there and in their own home.

One boy that stayed with me ages twelve years, when he went home his parents we far pleased when they saw how he acted, and the way he helped to the things and obeyed his parents.

The school children are learning well and are making excellent progress.

I am yours sincerely,

Mrs. Mary Ann Edger.

Sir,

I have the honour to state that regarding the six (6) pupils attending the Kitsegukla Indian Day School, and for that purpose are in residence and keep at the Mission there, and for whom each the Department at present makes the allowance of $5.00 per month, I have been requested by Mrs. Mary Anne Edgar to ask if something additional thereto for each of such pupil could be procured, to make it include the current quarter, and at which request Horace C. Wrinch, M.D., in charge of the Methodist Missions in these upper parts of the Skeena, joins.

In support thereof, I can state that in the premises the said pupils are extremely well taken care of, and for their use much of larger clothing is being remodelled and fitted; and by Mrs. Edgar the children are regularly being bathed, and those of the girl pupils (4) are being trained in house-keeping and other domestic science.

In view of the high prices of provisions prevailing, I beg to recommend that an additional allowance of at least $1.00 per each pupil (6) per month may kindly be granted.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Re- General Conditions Animaul and Kitsequickla Indian Reserves

SIR:

On the 20th last I left the detachment on patrol to the above mentioned reserves, per 3.H.2013.

Animaul village appears to be deserted at present, the people being away either hunting or engaged in the Cedar pole industry. I met an Indian from this village as a camp on the other side of the river, which I visited but he was away at the time.

At Kitsequickla I visited the schoolmaster, who reported that everything was alright in the village at present, and told me that should he hear or see anything wrong, he would communicate with us as soon as possible. He was very pleased with the attendance at school and the general run of things in the village. They have just got over an epidemic of flu in the village, without any deaths resulting from it.

Hazelton Detachment usually covers this reserve, but the trail has been impassible for a car during the last month or so, but it is fairly easy to reach from here, as long as the ice is on the river.

The trail was in fairly good shape, although the soft snow made it hard going for a saddle horse.

I arrived back at the detachment at about 7.30 P.M. of the same date; distance covered 45 miles.

Dear Mr. MacInnes,

I am a teacher at an Indian School at Kitasooxla B.C., Babine Agency. I am writing for information on the law governing Indian Schools and teachers. In case a teacher falls sick is any provision made for a substitute?

According to our B.C. School law we are allowed a number of days with pay, and the substitute—
is paid by the Government. Is there such arrangement re Indian teachers?

Take my own case, I was sick for 19 days in the Hazelton Hospital and several days with friends confined to the house.

My sickness was "Stomach Flu" caught no doubt from the natives. One is more exposed here than in a white school. I have to visit in missionary homes, administer drugs all hours of the day, and the teacherage is a disgrace—“a refrigerator” merely a shell, rustic on studs, and Beaver board on inside, nailed on studs, open to wind.
I have stoves red hot, and in cold weather I sit and shiver by the fire, 
with my overcoat on. I wouldn't live like this, but for the fact that 
I had a cold from November until Feb., when 
I was taken on a stretcher to the Hospital.

Now the school was closed for two weeks, Capt. Mortimer did his best, he tried 
locally and in Prince Rupert, but could not get a supply anywhere. Finally he asked 
D.W. Hilton an Indian, a graduate of the Edmonton Residential School, to supply for 
twelve days. He did good work, and expected to receive satisfactory remuneration.
He would have taught longer but I was anxious to be back. I started work on the Wabasso.

On my return I filled up five days learning only a week without any school. Surely I did my best for the Department.

Now I understand from a letter received in the Office at Hazelton that your department is not going to pay this young man? I feel it is a slight on me. I personally assured him you would pay. I never thought for a moment it would be otherwise. Now this young man feels very keenly that an injustice has been done him. I have to live here
I feel we must give these Indians fair-play. If it had been a white school, and he a white man, he could have gone to a court of justice and got his rights, but he is an Indian.

I didn't engage him as a teacher, if I had, I would pay him. My salary is so small considering my qualifications and opportunities that I think, rightly or wrongly, I am entitled to three weeks sick pay in two years? If not please let me know what the Indian School law does allow, if it allows anything.
I am not complaining. I am asking so that I can make my future plans on a reasonable basis. I wouldn't care to have another case like this in Kitasooxla.

These young men are not fools; they are no longer children, and they know what is right. This young man could have earned $3.50 a day or at least $2.50 in loggers' camps which he left in order to teach school. Personally I think the very least he should be paid is $2.50 a day, $24.00 in all.

Now this is a personal letter and absolutely confidential. I write as a man to a man.
I don't want you to even mention it to Capt. Mortimer. We are the very best of friends. I like Capt. Mortimer; he has been a gentleman to me and I have had nothing but the kindest consideration, and deepest interest in my work, from him. I wouldn't injure him if I could, nor allow a shadow to cross his administration. I am satisfied with him.

Please write me direct. Whatever the cost I must have justice done these Indians at least in my personal affairs. If the Department cannot pay well I guess I must. Though I may feel the injustice.
Well I am better able to bear it than an Indian, with my centuries of Christian love and righteousness as a background.

Trusting you will consider this very long letter, I consider you are my head—it is from you anyway that my commission came—forgive any seeming bitterness, I don't feel that way.

Yours very truly,

Bishop Black

Honoured Sir:

Your letter of May 4 reached me today and I wish to express my deepest gratitude for the confidence the Department has placed in me. The reason for writing my previous letter was that Mr. J. H. Burley was leaving and I did not wish to find my future jeopardized by an instant dismissal after our Conference had been which would be in a few days now, I would have been stranded.

As I stated in my letter I knew no personal reason why I should not return for another year or years. Certainly the verbal report given me by Capt. Inspector Barry was not perfect, but he led me to believe he was satisfied. The only criticism was of my Grade I class which he said was the worst in the Agency. This was easily explained, all the other schools had been in regular session for a whole month, my children only a few days, some came that very day for the first time after a three or
In many cases four months' vacation. One could not expect 6 and 7 year olds, who at best get only five months in a school year, to know much so soon. You will recall the school was not open for two months longer.

Personally, I am working for the children. I am perfectly satisfied with my own accomplishments, thank God I have a clear conscience and this gives me continuous inward peace. But I wanted to know that you are satisfied, your letter has assured me that you are and now I have confidence to go forward (PD) for another year of service in a work I love.

I must confess it is very hard work but I am getting splendid results. Children who had been on the register 4 years when I came couldn't read a first primer today they read well any part of Grade II Reader. Others I took in two years ago, can already read well a first primer; next fall they can start Highroads.

On every hand I have had compliments from the parents praising my work and assuring me that their children have never made such rapid progress in so short a time as under my present tutelage. These are the real wages, my meagre salary is a mere pittance, when you consider the hours of service I render. Often after spending an evening settling some domestic quarrel or visiting the sick, in some cases travelling three miles in the cold to phone the doctor for advice.
I come home and work until midnight preparing my lessons for the kiddies. I believe in giving them my very best of mind as well as affection. Again I say I have had my reward, the boy in 7th Grade often asks on Friday night (not for the funnies) but a text book on History, Geography or Science. I am pestered to death with even younger children coming for books to read. I have exhausted my own resources. You will remember my former request for a school library—Capt. Baring did not favour it—so I dropped the idea. I am buying, begging from friends, all the children's books I can get. It seems to me foolish to create a thirst for reading and supply no water.

If only I had the time there is a great work among the young people I could do; they are always asking for evening classes, they say, "We want to read like your school children read." Unfortunately for a few years my dear wife cannot join me, (nervous trouble due to over-study) she would be such a help, being an expert primary teacher, a B.A. with honours B.C. University, and a graduate in music. Perhaps sometime we may be able to live a normal life again. My present task is absolutely impossible, I teach, at least, am often in the school until 4-30 p.m. or 5 p.m. from 5 p.m. until 11 p.m.
I serve drugs, bind up wounds, give advice even to the care and feeding of babies. I even had a request to attend a woman in childbirth—no one else they could trust "being handy," they said. I had to assure them only a doctor or nurse could attend such cases.

The United Church a few weeks ago gave me an unanimous invitation to return as their minister. They said, "We are wrong and do wrong, you are right—a good man we want you to stay with us for years." One man said, "while I live." It's a great ideal (ideal) to have to live up to, but I believe in God who is sufficient.

I gather from your letter that Dr. G. Dorsey called upon you and together you arranged for my return to Kteewinoka School Sept. 1-1739. I wish to express again my deepest and most heartfelt thanks, to you personally, also to the Department for this happy cooperation with our Church in the work of training and educating the Indian people.

With sincerest regards,

I remain, Yours very truly,

Bishop Black.

Dear Mr. Hanson:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of February 22 and also a letter and resolution, relating to the operation of the above noted school, enclosed therewith.

The records here indicate that the attendance of pupils at Indian day schools during the month of September has never been satisfactory at any time in recent years. This condition exists on such large reserves as Iyendiniga and Six Nations in Ontario and exists also in outlying districts throughout the Dominion. Indian agents have from time to time sought to explain that the nomadic habits of the Indians, berry-picking, fishing, the harvesting of potatoes both in Canada and the United States and general farm work at that particular season of the year have all contributed to lack of attendance at our schools.

When the work of this Branch was carefully reviewed, in the light of the critical events now confronting us, and when an attempt was made to conserve to the utmost extent possible the public funds at our disposal for the regular services and for the Nation's war effort, it was decided, for the time being at least, to operate our schools on a 9 month rather than a 10 month basis. I should perhaps point out that the Premier of Ontario,

Olof Hanson, Esq., M. P.,
House of Commons,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6398, File 822-1, part 1)
about the same time that this decision was reached by our Branch, announced that the public schools of Ontario would remain closed until the first teaching day in October. The Premier, in his announcement, stated that this action had been taken in an attempt to solve the labour problem in the province. You are aware, no doubt, that a large number of white schools in the drought-stricken regions of western Canada have been operating on a 9 month rather than a 10 month basis for a number of years. Indeed, it can be stated that a number of these schools have been operating on an 8 month basis. In other words, the taxpayers of Canada have been providing the funds to keep Indian day and residential schools in operation on a 10 month basis while many of their own schools were operating, annually, on an 8 and 9 month basis.

Our schools in British Columbia are inspected from time to time by an Inspector who is an employee of this Branch. This Inspector, in his recent reports, has expressed the opinion that it is quite possible for a pupil to complete the annual course of study in a 9 month period, provided the attendance of the pupil is regular and not interrupted by sickness.

The decision to operate Indian schools for the shorter period was reached after very careful consideration had been given to the matter, and I am not at all hopeful that this period will be extended at any time in the immediate future. No provision for the operation of Indian day schools on a 10 month basis has been made in the 1941-42 estimates.

I am returning herewith the letter and resolution received by you from Mr. Jones.

Resolution presented by the residents of the Village of Kitsegukla to the meeting of the Prince Rupert Presbytery of the United Church, held in Prince Rupert, Feb. 5 - 6, 1941.

The residents of the village of Kitsegukla deeply regret that the Department of Indian Affairs closed the school for three months in the summer of 1940 and urgently request that this meeting of the Prince Rupert Presbytery of the United Church pass a resolution strongly urging that the school be kept open for ten months during the year 1941, for the following reasons:

1. All Provincial schools for white children at which schools Indian children whose parents are taxpayers and residents may attend, are open for ten months each year.

2. The handicap of language requires that the Indian children should have at least as much time in school each year as the white children, especially as they follow mainly the same course of study.

3. The school is the main force in the community for building Canadians, and Canada has no more loyal subjects than the Indians.

4. The break of three months is too long to keep apart children, parents and teachers.

5. The reduction of the teacher's salary by one tenth means that good teachers will not remain in the schools - in fact they will not consider even coming to the schools. Indian schools require good teachers and they should be encouraged to teach and remain in these schools.

Dear Sir,

We are in receipt of your letter addressed to the Treasurer of Indian Affairs Branch, dated April 2, 1942.

It should be noted that calculations for the purpose of computing National Defence Tax are based on an assumed calendar year basis of gross salary; in your case it is considered that your yearly salary could amount to $1,140.00 per annum plus a cost of living bonus of $142.92, and, as this amount would be over the maximum of $1200.00 per annum you would automatically be subject to National Defence Tax deduction of 5%. The department has no alternative but to make these deductions from salary as the rules and regulations for the application of National Defence Tax embodied in the Act distinctly state that an employer, which in this case is the department, must make the necessary deduction from all salaries that are taxable.

To recover any portion of this tax, application must be made by the employee direct to the Inspector of Income Tax for his district.

Trusting the above information may be of assistance to you,

Yours truly,

In reply to your letter of June 22, I wish to advise that many families of this reserve proceed to the canneries early in May for the spring salmon fishing. Kitsegukla Indians are also proud of their gardens, and several school-aged children help with the seeding. Both are causes of irregular attendance.

Privies will be inspected on my next visit and washing facilities will be remedied for the next school year.

Dear Sir: For some weeks I've been debating as to whether I would continue as missionary teacher for another term.

After looking at the problem from all angles I have finally decided I must sever my connections here to take place effect at the end of Dec. 1944.

Re: Kitsegukla Day School

District School Inspector Davey, early in September, interviewed a Mrs. S. Dubno, an applicant for the position of teacher at the above mentioned school and apparently was satisfied with her qualifications and instructed her to assume her duties as soon as she could. A review of our files in connection with this school reveals that the Department was not advised of the assignment of Mrs. Dubno, apparently for the reason that she omitted to complete and return to this office application, questionnaire and T.D. 1 forms, which omission might have gone unnoticed even longer had not been noticed. Boys under date of September 27th advised that Mrs. Dubno was suffering from some type of nervous breakdown and requested a transfer to a less isolated school.

As Inspector Davey was proceeding north at the time the matter was left in abeyance until he had an opportunity to interview her. Word received from Mr. Davey indicates that Mrs. Dubno was not suitable for employment as a teacher in even less isolated schools than Kitsegukla and she has agreed to resign effective October 30th. We anticipate receiving application and other forms from Mrs. Dubno which will be forwarded immediately. I would recommend that on receipt of these forms Mrs. Dubno be paid salary for the period September 23rd, the date she assumed her duties, to October 30th, which will provide her with sufficient funds for her return to Vancouver which, I might say, is not possible at the moment because of lack of funds.

With regard to a replacement, I am enclosing an application form from Miss Margaret Wernock, an experienced
qualified teacher. I have not interviewed Miss Warnock but of the vacancies offered to her she has expressed a preference for Kitsegukla and I would recommend her assignment to that school.

We have Inspector Davey's letter of the 31st ultimo enclosing application of Mr. Thomas Henry Butters for a position as teacher at the Kitsegukla Indian Day School.

We have a new schedule of salaries for teachers of Indian Day Schools which will become effective on September 1st, 1947. Full particulars regarding the new schedule will be contained in the Indian School Bulletin while will be issued shortly.

As Mr. Butters has no professional training we can only allow him salary at the rate of $100.00 a teaching month.

I enclose herewith an application of Mr. Thomas Henry Butters for the position of teacher at the Kitsegukla Indian Day School.

Mr. Butters has already been referred to the United Church authorities and I understand that they are prepared to nominate him for this position.

I have contacted the references given in his application and both Mr. Kennedy and Miss Maycock speak very highly of the candidate. Mr. Butters is prepared to remain in the service for at least a year at the end of which time he hopes to be in a position to attend Normal School. It is noted that Mr. Butters has had no professional training but in view of the present teacher shortage and his academic qualifications I am prepared to recommend that Mr. Butters be appointed as teacher at the Kitsegukla Indian Day School at a salary of $120.00 per month for a period of not more than 10 months commencing September 1st, 1947.

R.F. Davey,

Ottawa, October 16th, 1928.

Reverend Sir,

I beg to refer you to official letter of July 16th last with reference to the securing of a teacher for the Kitsegukla Indian Day School. The Department does not appear to have received any reply from you regarding this matter but the September quarter return of the school has just been received and it shows a Mr. Ede in charge.

In forwarding the return, Mr. Indian Agent Hyde draws attention to the fact that, previous to the opening of the school, he had not received any intimation in connection with Mr. Ede's appointment. Please let me know, as soon as possible, if Mr. Ede was nominated by you and, also, the salary which you recommend be paid. From the quarterly return submitted by Mr. Ede, it is shown that, while he arrived at the school on September 6th, he did not begin teaching until September 17th. MEMORANDUM:

Representative of the Treasury.

Re: School No. 822.

Owing to the sudden death of Mr. R. H. Goodridge, teacher of the Kitsegukla Indian Day School, Mr. Irving W. Bell has been appointed temporary teacher until June 30th, next, with salary at the rate of $95 a teaching month.

As Mr. Bell began duties on March 12th, 1936, he is entitled to 20/31 of salary for March, or $61.29; plus salary for April - $95.00, or a total of $156.29. The following entry should, therefore, appear on the April paylist:

Dear Mr. Scott:

On the Kitzequela Reserve at the site of the old village the Department has no school building of any kind. Fire issues have been rented from time to time for use of school. About two years ago they were burnt down. Subsequently to that school was held in the church owned by the Methodist Church on the Reserve. During this winter this was found to be too cold for the children, and the teacher moved his school work into a room of a building which he occupied as his residence, which of course is not by any means satisfactory.

The Indians themselves are moving in the matter and have now come to me with a definite proposition over the signature of seventeen of the leading Indians of the Band to the effect that if the Department will pay $500.00 towards it, they will themselves provide the balance of material and labour and erect a school.

It appears to me that this is a very favorable offer and I would recommend its acceptance by the Department.

If this offer is approved by the Department, and we could be so advised without delay, the Indians would still have time to get out logs to their little saw-mill so that the lumber could be cut this Spring, and the building erected during the summer. I would like to see this done, and would appreciate an early reply so that it could be facilitated.

I remain

Yours respectfully,

Acting Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott,

re. school building for the Kitsegukla Reserve.

At present there is no school building on this reserve. The Department has always rented a building at this point. The former school was burned about two years ago and, since that time, the school has been carried on in the church owned by the Methodist Church and the Department pays a rent of $5.00 per month for the use of the building. The church has been found to be cold during the winter and the teacher has moved the school into a room of the building which he occupies as his residence. This school is conducted under the auspices of the Methodist Church, and, during the past two years, there have been good teachers and there has also been a good attendance of pupils. The enrolment for the past quarter was 22, with an average attendance of 17.

Mr. Acting Agent Wrinch now informs the Department that the Indians themselves have come to him with a definite proposition over the signatures of seventeen of the leading Indians of the band to the effect that, if the Department will provide $500.00 towards a new building, they will themselves provide the balance of the material and the labour to erect the building. The Acting Agent states that he considers this a very favourable offer and recommends it for acceptance and requests to be advised without delay, in order that the Indians will have time to get out logs to their saw-mill so that the lumber could be cut this spring and the building erected during the coming summer. The Indians on this reserve take an active interest in the education of their children.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Sir James Loughheed -

The school on the Kitsogukla reserve, Hazelton agency, B.C., was destroyed by fire some two years ago. Since that time the school has been conducted in the building owned by the Methodist church, for which we pay a rent of $5.00 per month. This building was so unsatisfactory that the teacher found it necessary during the winter months to move into a room of the building which he occupies as a residence.

The school on this reserve has been one of our successful day schools, the enrolment during the past quarter being 22 and the average attendance 17. The Indians have come to the acting Indian agent, Dr. Wrinch, with a proposition to the effect that if the Department will provide $500.00 towards a new building, they themselves will provide the balance of the material and the labour to erect it. They have a saw-mill where necessary lumber can be cut. Dr. Wrinch recommends the acceptance of this offer and asks to be advised without delay.

In view of the circumstances I think we should encourage these Indians to this extent. Payment can be made from the school appropriation and with your consent I shall authorize expenditure taking necessary steps at the same time to secure the Department for any expenditure that will be made.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Ottawa, April 2, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd ultimo, in which you inform the Department of the proposition made by the leading Indians of the Kitseguklia Band to erect a building for school purposes and state that, if the Department will provide the sum of $500.00 for the purpose, the Indians themselves will get out the logs, have the lumber sawn and furnish the labour in the erection of the building.

In reply I beg to say that this matter having been submitted to the Superintendent General he has approved of the granting of the sum of $500.00 to assist the Indians in putting up a suitable building for school purposes. You have not furnished any particulars as to the kind of building it is proposed to erect, the dimensions of the same, nor who will oversee the work and advise the Indians during construction. The Department would have to receive assurance that the building will be completed and will be suitable for the purpose of providing accommodation for the Indian children of school age in the band. You should furnish the Department with full particulars regarding the type of building and the dimensions of the same and also how you would propose that the grant allowed by the Department should be expended for the purpose, and also who would be responsible for seeing that the work is satisfactorily performed. If the amount of the Department's grant is expended in the purchase of material, it will be necessary to obtain competitive prices before the purchase is made and proper vouchers will have to be submitted covering the expenditure.

If you are satisfied that the Indians are capable of performing the work, you may instruct them to proceed and get out the logs and have the lumber sawn, and, as soon as you have furnished particulars as asked for regarding the manner in which the building is to be erected and how it is proposed to utilise the amount which the Department will provide, you will be further instructed before undertaking any expenditure. The building should be erected in as central a locality as possible and the site should be high and dry and easily drained. An early reply, giving the particulars asked for, should be furnished.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. C. Brinch, Esq., M.D.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Haselton, B.C.

Ottawa, August 19, 1921

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, regarding the erection of a new day school building at Kitsegukla and submitting a sketch of the proposed building, as well as quantities of building material required and quotations on same.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery on the ground of the quantity of lumber and other material required. It is noted that you have obtained prices from two firms for the greater part of the lumber required and that submitted by G. Little of Terrace, is satisfactory.

Before the purchase of any other material is made it will also be necessary to obtain competitive prices and you should purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price. The sketch submitted of the proposed building is satisfactory.

It is noted that the Indians will furnish all the labour in the erection of the building without charge to the Department and that they are capable of doing the work. The work should be undertaken as soon as possible and completed before the winter sets in. The work should be under the direct supervision of Mr. Orchard and should be completed to his and your satisfaction.

It will be necessary for you to obtain itemized accounts from the firms from whom you make the purchase of the material and you should certify the same and forward to the Department for payment. You should attach a memo to the account showing the names of the firms asked to quote a price and the prices quoted by them for all material used.

Your obedient servant,

The teacher of the Kitsegukla Indian Day School, in her return for the quarter ended June 30th, last, states as follows:

"The schoolhouse is very cold in winter - almost unbearable. It would be advisable to line the walls with beaver board, and put another floor on the top of the present one.

Another matter which requires attending to is the building of toilets; there are none.

A brick chimney also is needed."

I have to request that you will report on the requirements as mentioned by the teacher, stating whether you would recommend that the work be carried out. Please give an estimate of the cost of all the above work, and state how you would advise that it be carried out. This matter should receive your prompt attention in order that, if these repairs are authorized, they can be completed before the cold weather sets in.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

E. Hyde, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hazelton, B.C.

Sir:

The Department will approve of an expenditure of approximately $30 in having this work carried out as soon as weather conditions permit next spring. You should, therefore, bear this matter in mind and arrange for the necessary labour in having the work done.

Dear Sir:

I beg to call your kind attention to the necessity of having the land surrounding the Indian Day School and Teacher's residence at Kitsegukla cleared of brush and timber.

Last Summer during the hot dry weather the small brush was a constant menace to the safety of the above buildings. I have got over the area which is about an acre and have estimated the cost of clearing at some $30.00, including burning.

I should like to have your permission to have the work done sometime next Spring.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

re - Arthur McDames of Kitsegukla Reserve.

In reply to your letter of April 4th, No. 151-15-5, dealing with a $50.00 claim for materials supplied by Arthur McDames of Kitsegukla, I respectfully beg to state that I have had this matter under investigation for some considerable time and I am of opinion that McDames did supply lumber on January 3rd 1921 to Mr. E. A. Orchard, teacher of the Kitsegukla Indian Day School at that time. Lumber, which was supplied, was used for building a shed, in the nature of a large covered-in verandah, in front of the Day School at Kitsegukla. Investigations go to show that Mr. Orchard had ordered the lumber without any authority but had informed the Indian that, if the Church Mission did not pay for it, he would try and get the Indian Department to do so. Apparently no further action was taken in the matter by Mr. Orchard and there is no data in this office concerning the erection of this porch.

Repeated applications have been made to me by McDames for reimbursement and after due consideration, and finding this Indian - who is a married man and a cripple - in reduced circumstances, I have made arrangements to give him the regular monthly relief in lieu of pay or material. He readily consented to take relief and has been issued with same for March and April.

I trust this meets with the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

G. C. Mortimer,

Sir,

re - Painting of Indian Day School and Teacher's Residence at Kitsegukla.

I respectfully beg to reply to your letter of November 9th, 1931, No. 151-15-5, dealing with the matter of the above mentioned unpainted buildings at Kitsegukla.

During my recent visit to the village I examined these buildings and I am of opinion that they should be painted this summer, although it is quite possible that the buildings would not be in the least damaged by waiting another year. The cost of paint would be $4.25 per gallon but I cannot say what quantity will be needed as the buildings have never yet been painted. Indian labour could be utilized at $2.50 per day.

Owing to the last winter being long and severe no painting could have been done earlier than the present month and even now the weather is rather cold for painting. The Kitsegukla village is practically isolated from early December to early May, therefore you can readily see the reason for delay in this report.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing requisition for Kallomine to the walls of the teacher's residence.

As you know they badly want painting & this seems the most convenient time for the work.

Yours faithfully,

A. H. Goodridge

Sheena Crossing
Sept 28th 34
The present room is some 25 feet by 17 feet with the long sides on the North and South. The interior is lined with shiplap lumber which was put on green and has shrunk. The floor was laid with green lumber and is very poor now.

The whole of the West end of the school room should be moved out another ten feet, the roof and sides of the building being extended at the same time. A new porch turned towards the teacher's cottage on the South side of the school should be constructed, as well as a small woodshed to care for the wood now kept in the entrance to the school.

The present entrance through the woodshed should be done away with and the lumber used in the new porch. A complete new floor should then be laid.

The two old windows at present in the South side of the school should be taken out and placed with two new windows and the present two to make a total of six windows along the North side of the new schoolroom.

Four lengths of Asbestoslate Board each four feet by eight feet will then be required and these should be placed at a convenient height for children along the South and East interior walls. The remainder of the interior will need to be lined with these ply or plaster board.

The school as well as the teacher's cottage is the property of the Indian Affairs Branch I understand.

It is hard to estimate what the whole of the above reconstruction of the school would cost, but I consider that the sum of $750.00 should be inserted in the Estimates for the fiscal year 1938-39 to cover the material and work. I have informed the Acting Indian Agent that I could not recommend this work this year as it is not as urgent as that.

I do however consider that a large heater of the circulatory pattern should be placed in this school this summer in time for school opening in September. The cost of a large enough heater of this kind would be around $60.00 and it could of course be used in the reconstructed school should my suggestion be carried out later.

EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR BARRY'S REPORT REGARDING HIS INSPECTION OF THE KITSEGULIA INDIAN DAY SCHOOL ON MAY 26, 1937.

Suggested reconstruction of school building:

The present room is some 25 feet by 17 feet with the long sides on the North and South. The interior is lined with shiplap lumber which was put on green and has shrunk. The floor was laid with green lumber and is very poor now.

The whole of the west end of the schoolroom should be moved out another ten feet, with roof and sides of the building being extended at the same time. A new porch turned towards the teacher's cottage on the south side of the school should be constructed, as well as a small woodshed to care for the wood now kept in the entrance to the school.

The present entrance through the woodshed should be done away with and the lumber used in the new porch.

A complete new floor should then be laid.

The two old windows at present in the south side of the school should be taken out and placed, with two new windows and the present two, to make a total of six windows along the north side of the new schoolroom.

Four lengths of Asbestoslate blackboard each four feet by eight feet will then be required and these should be placed at a convenient height for children along the south and east interior walls. The remainder of the interior will need to be lined with three ply or plaster board.

The school as well as the teacher's cottage is the property of the Indian Affairs Branch, I understand.

It is hard to estimate what the whole of the above reconstruction of the school would cost, but I consider that the sum of $750.00 should be inserted in the Estimates for the fiscal year 1938-39 to cover the material and work. I have informed the Acting Indian Agent that I could not recommend this work this year as it is not as urgent as that.

I do however consider that a large heater of the circulatory pattern should be placed in this school this summer in time for school opening in September. The cost of a large enough heater of this kind would be around $60.00 and it could, of course, be used in the reconstructed school should my suggestions be carried out later.

re - Voucher 276, $40.54, in favour of R.S. Sargent, Ltd., for Extra Material re Kitsegukla Indian Day School Extension.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O.
