With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $250.00 for repairs to the roof and interior and exterior painting at the Kitsegukla Indian Day School. It is noted that this amount will cover both material and labour. When forwarding the account for the material you should attach copy of your purchase order.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Mallinson's letter of the 4th ultimo requesting authority to expend $250.00 for roof repairs and interior and exterior painting of Kitsegukla Indian Day School, which was provided for in his current estimates. Some delay has occurred in this connection as it was necessary to refer the matter back to Mr. Mallinson for further details regarding the roof, copy of his reply of the 7th instant being enclosed herewith.

If funds are available, I would recommend approval of the application.

For D.M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
D.M. MacKay, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

re-Painting and Repairing of Kitsegukla Indian Day School Building.

In the 1943-44 Estimates an amount of $250.00 was entered to cover the above noted project. If this amount has been allotted, will you kindly procure authority for me to have the work carried out during the summer months when the school is closed?

Following is a list of the materials it is estimated will be required to complete the project:

6 Squares, Hexagon Asphalt Shingles @ 10.00 per Square 80.00

With reference to this item, I would advise that cedar shingles are un procurable here at the present time, and in any case I believe that if consideration is given to the durability of asphalt shingles, the fact that no paint or stain is required, and the fire protection provided by them, they would prove to be less expensive than cedar, over a period of time.

Exterior Paint:
10 gals. Outside Cream Approximate price 2.90 per gal
in 5 gal. tins 29.00
1 Brunswick Brown Approx. 3.00
1 White 1.65

Interior Paint:
4 gals. Light Gray approx. 3.50 per gal 14.00
1 Green 1.75
1 White 1.75
10 Pkgs. White Kalsomine .75 per Pkg. 7.50

It is considered that the balance of the estimated $250.00 total cost will be ample to cover the cost of labour, and incidentals such as paint brushes and turpentine which can be procured locally.

When authority is procured for carrying out this work,

p.t.o.
D.M. MacKay, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Your File 215-1-4779

re: Painting & Repairing of Kitsegukla Indian Day School Building.

The spaces between the roof boards, which in this case are very small, will not therefore matter.

S. Mallinson,

Re: Kitsegukla I.D. School.

With reference to your letter Dec. 2/43, I wish to advise you that the labor in connection with painting of both inside and outside of Kitsegukla I.D. School, has cost more than was at first estimated. For this work alone there were 360 hours of labor $.40 per hour, totaling $144.00. Three coats of paint had to be applied on all plain woodwork which added considerable to the number of hours. The price of $.40 per hour I considered particularly reasonable as a general payment is at least $.65 per hour.

The known accounts to date are as follows:

| Item                        | Cost   |
|-----------------------------|--------|
| Paint                       | $59.94 |
| Paint Brushes               | 15.15  |
| Shingles, F.O.B. Delivered  |        |
| Kitsegukla                  | 58.25  |
| Shingles, FOB Delivered, Vancouver | 25.27 |
| Shingle Tacks              | 6.00   |
| Labor (painting on y)      | 144.00 |

To which will be added freight on second shipment of shingles and labor of shingling.

It would appear from the above that the original estimate is almost $100.00 short of the actual cost and I would ask if you would kindly obtain authority, from the Department to cover this amount.

(Sgd.) S. Mallinson,
Indian Agent.
In reply to your letter of January 11th and previous correspondence I wish to advise you that I have investigated the time of 360 hours taken in painting both the inside and outside of the Kitsegukla school and I am certain no time was wasted in doing this work. The Indian concerned informs me that on several occasions he stayed up to half an hour longer in order to finish the part he was doing, but never charged extra time. I also figured out the time I considered it should have taken and there was not more than 8 hours difference. I wish to emphasize the fact that only .40c per hour was the wage agreed upon. This price is not more than half that paid for such work.

Besides the painting there were four blackboards badly cracked. These were taken down, the usable portions cut and four small but perfectly good blackboards framed and put up. Two other new blackboards were framed and also put up.

Arrangements were made for the work to be done on September 7th 1943 and five visits were made while the work was in progress.

I am enclosing a voucher with attached accounts for the painting and shingling the roof of the school, together with an account for the material not previously submitted.

I am advised by the Reverend W. P. Bunt that he has recommended the nomination of Mrs. B.N. Kitchenmaster as teacher of the Kitsegukla Indian Day School. Mr. Bunt advises that Mrs. Kitchenmaster is exceptionally well qualified and experienced, and if conditions at the village are satisfactory would like to remain for some time. In view of this it is considered advisable that some repairs be carried out to the teacher's residence and that a few items of furnishings be supplied. Mr. Mallinson estimates that repairs and alterations to the teacherage would cost approximately $360.00; this amount to provide for the removal of a partition and painting of the interior of the building. Although no specific provision was made in the estimates for this expenditure, there are a number of other improvements provided for which will not likely be carried out and if funds are available it is recommended that Mr. Mallinson be authorized to proceed with the work on submission of full details through this office.

Dear Mr Ferrier,

Your letter of the 20th March to hand.

As I informed you at Prince Rupert, we have not opened school at Kitselas (New Town) since the New Year.

There are eighteen children of school age in the village here. There is a population of eighty on the Reserve. My work consists chiefly of preaching and also assisting all I can as Chairman of the Village Committee. We have church services on Sunday at 11.00 a.m., 3.00 p.m., and 7.00 p.m., also on Tuesdays and Fridays at 7.30. The school certainly ought to be opened with the least possible delay. It is shameful the way we have been held up in this important part of our work. When we came to New Town at the end of May 1911 we found no equipment whatever to carry on our work, save an old register and four or five badly torn readers, 2nd Primers. There were no slates or any other material. I wrote to the chairman of the District and also to Mr Green, School Inspector, about supplies. We opened school and did our best without help until the end of June, when school closed for the holidays, and I was down at the mouth of the Skeena preaching the Gospel at the
Canneries. The school was re-opened after the holidays on August 29th, (Friday) by Bro. Deans. I got up in September and relieved him. No supplies had come. I received a schedule from Mr. Raley to fill in, showing what our needs were. This was attended to at once, and forwarded at once to Indian Agent Loring at Hazleton. He told me that he had sent my request to Ottawa and that books and other things would soon be here. Handicapped as we were, we continued to teach school up until Christmas. We had written to Mr. Loring several times, and also to Mr. Raley, explaining the difficulty we were in, trying to hold the children and instruct them without books. Mr. Loring assured us the books would be here any time, and we postponed opening school until these arrived. So far we have seen no sign of them and have lost practically three months work. Had a letter from Mr. Loring last week and he tells me now that he has been in touch with the Department at Ottawa and hoped to have my supplies here soon. In February I visited him at Hazleton and while there he promised he would do his best to get a grant for the school house at New Town. The school is at present held in the church, which was built entirely by the people, save for a grant of $100.00 from the Missionary Society, and the Government has not spent a penny on buildings here. The old church was burned down some time years ago, whether that was built with the assistance of the Government we do not know. The people would very much like a school house, so the church would be kept for the regular services only. The children
do not give the chairs the best sort of treatment. But at present what we do need and must have if our work is to go on is books and slates as we asked for in that schedule. I think this puts our position clearly.

on
New Town Indian Day School, Kitselas, Babine Age

Sir,

I have the honor to report that on my way down the Skeena River I visited the Indian village of New Town (Kitselas) at the request of the Indians. They called a meeting and spoke at great length requesting a school house, and help for the school, from the Department.

Mr. Lewis Edgar, a married man with five children, has taught school for one year. He has had an average of twelve. There are about twenty children of school age in the village, healthy, bright children, and they are doing well in their studies, in fact considering that he has poor equipment, especially well. The teacher had purchased a few small books, slates, a few bibles and hymn books.

The village has improved greatly during the year that Mr. Edgar has been there. The Indians are now able to keep the drunken men off the reserve, and the village is orderly. The teacher has a splendid garden, fruits, vegetables, and flowers, and the Indians are trying to imitate him. At the time of my visit he was showing them how to plant garden seeds. He is also a good carpenter and shows them how to build.

The Indians themselves have built a good church, nicely seated with chairs. The school is held in this, but some of the Indians object, they complain it scratches the chairs, and they wish for a separate building.

The village is beautifully situated, the land excellent, the people progressive, and worth encouraging. I would respectfully recommend that this school receive assistance from the Department.

Mr. Edgar is a most valuable man on the reserve. When I visited the village a year ago, a month before he went to the village,
I find five drunken white men there, and the Indians unable to send them away. This is all changed, the teacher has shown good tact in dealing with white men. "Van Arsdale" Station on the G.T.R.R., the terminus of the line from Prince Rupert, is only a quarter of a mile away from the village, and hundreds of navvies and all sorts of people get to this point by rail, then often stay days before starting up river on ice, etc. Many of them go to the reserve to get shelter and food. Only by the watchfulness of the teacher have the Indians been able to protect themselves from being demoralized.

The officials of the Railway told me that they admired the good sense of Mr. Edgar in dealing with the people, and that he had assisted much in keeping order, and preventing drinking.

I have the honor to remain

Your obedient servant

Inspector.

Dear Sir:

I have been told by certain of our church officials who are also connected with the Indian Dept., that you are liberal-minded in regard to advancing the work of Indian schools and always ready to help along the cause with which you have been so long connected. I have been teaching Indian schools now for eight years and have found it at times a great drag and very monotonous. The average Indian child is slow to grasp the essentials of a common education but on the contrary, is naturally gifted in a mechanical sense. What he sees, feels or touches, or in other words—object lessons—appeal to him. This part of a child's education is becoming more and more practiced in all our schools, but from my practical experience in India...
schools I feel the need is imperative in connection with the education of our Indian children.

In connection with the Kitzeloo school with which I have been connected for over three years, I find the situation even more exhausting of energy and requiring more tact and patience than in either the Skidegate or Fort Simpson schools with which I was connected for two years in each. This school has a very small average attendance and the children are nearly all in the Primer or low grade classes. It has been very difficult to keep up enthusiasm as an incentive to steady attendance or a desire to push ahead and advance so I have been thinking seriously over the whole situation as to how I might make school life more attractive and have been wondering whether you would give your permission to allow the purchase of a limited
supply of mechanical toys that would have an educative value. He is handy with tools and is a good mechanic, considering all the chances he has had to learn. For the boys I would suggest a set of Meccano which costs up to $20 according to the amount purchased. This game would be entertaining, instructive and of an educative value. For the girls, I have not yet made a selection but feel confident something suitable can be found. I honestly believe that if these toys were in our school, it would be an attractive as well as an educative agency, which would mean a great deal toward supplementing book study.

Trusting you will give this subject your special and hopeful best from you very truly,

Yours truly,

J.H. [signature]

Sir:

I beg to inform the Department of the resignation of Mr. Hewson as teacher of the Kitselas Day School. The Rev. Dr. Usterhout, Superintendent of Indian missions of the United Church, has written nominating Miss Marjorie Kenny, and I quote, as follows, from his letter:

"Since conversing with you recently about the Vanarsdol school and the work of Mr. Hewson as teacher there, I have returned home to find that Mr. Hewson has accepted a position offered by the School Board of Terrace, giving us scarcely two weeks to find a successor. It goes without saying that we are very disappointed over this change in the situation as, with yourself, we felt that the Hewsons were giving very fine service among the Kitselas people.

An application has come from Miss Marjorie Kenny, a daughter of Mr. E. T. Kenny Esq., M. L. A., of Terrace and although she is but 18 years of age and quite inexperienced we feel that perhaps her appointment for one year would be the best arrangement under the circumstances. Her youth is a decided objection but being of a representative family well known to the Indians and so near at home also, the age question may not be so much stressed in her case. She states that suitable boarding arrangements can be made and I presume she will be able to get home occasionally for the weekend. The reason why the "one year" appointment is stressed is because we feel strongly that a married male teacher is decidedly better for such a school, a male leader being much more acceptable to the Indians and the home of such being a decided advantage to the community as a social and religious centre. It will be our avowed aim to secure such a teacher for next year."
I am not in favour of the appointment as Kitselas is not a suitable place for a young girl without experience. However, the appointment is to be for one year only, and I hope when the next appointment is made it will be possible to obtain the services of a married man or older person with experience. In view of the fact that the time is short and schools re-open this week, I would endorse the nomination.

Your obedient servant,

W.E. Collison,
Indian Agent.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR FEBRUARY.

At Kitselas we were able to make an amicable settlement between the United Church and the Kitselas People; and the Christian Band of Workers over the church buildings and property. The real cause of the dispute was that rent of the church building when used as a school had been paid to the United Church instead of to the Christian Band of Workers. The latter, to all intents and purposes, were owners of the building but unfortunately had not been functioning properly in recent years.

Rev. M. Bunt, Superintendent of United Church Missions, agreed with the agent's suggestion that the rental be returned to the Christian Band of Workers through the Indian Agency Trust Account, if and when that organization had legally elected its officers, the money to be used only for repairs to the church building at Kitselas.

Dear Doctor Cochrane:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 1st, in which you send forward additional information, received by you from Mr. Hunt, in respect to the nomination of a teacher for the above-noted school.

I must express regret that a misunderstanding seems to exist in regard to this matter. A careful survey of the files shows that Mr. H. Peacock, Chief Secretary of the Salvation Army in Canada, interviewed the Director of this Branch on December 8th, 1925. Mr. Peacock, during the course of this interview, stated that he had no objection whatever to the work of the teacher then in charge of the Kitselas School. He did feel, however, that should the teacher resign at any time, the Salvation Army should have the privilege of nominating her successor. Mr. Peacock informed the Director that practically all the children attending the school are the children of Salvation Army soldiers. On December 9th, 1925, instructions were received from the Director by the officers of the Welfare and Training Division that when a vacancy occurred at this school the desirability of having the Salvation Army nominate the teacher should be very carefully and very sympathetically reviewed, and on December 27th, 1925, a letter was written to Mr. Peacock, in which we stated that these instructions from the Director would be acted upon when the nomination of a teacher for the school came up for review.

On June 2nd, 1926, a petition signed by Chief M.C. McKay, Chief Waiter Wright and a large number of Indian parents of the Kitselas Band, was received by the Department. In this petition they requested a Salvation Army teacher for their Indian day school. The petitioners in their appeal stated:

"Since all our people, with the exception of two families who belong to the Christian Band of Workers, are members of the Salvation Army, we would like you to permit the Salvation Army to submit to you an application for a fully qualified teacher for this school. While the United Church have no membership in our village, they have been permitted to supply teachers for the school, but we would now ask that this be discontinued and that in future the Salvation Army be allowed to supply the teacher."

The Department was notified by Dr. Dorey, in a letter dated July 18th, 1942, that Mrs. Robert Wilson was anxious to transfer to the Cape Mudge School, and this transfer was approved in a letter dated July 21st, 1942.

the same date an air mail letter was sent forward to Indian Commissioner MacKay by Mr. Phelan. On July 31st Major MacKay replied, sending forward a copy of a letter received by him from Indian Agent Gillett. A copy of the Indian Agent's letter was forwarded to Dr. Dorey on August 4th. Major MacKay in his letter states:

"I would advise that I have enquired of Mr. Indian Agent Gillett and enclose his letter herewith - from which it appears that almost the entire reserve are adherents to the Salvation Army. In my opinion, therefore, this denomination might be requested to nominate a teacher for the vacant position."

This letter has the printed signature of Major MacKay but is also signed by Inspector Coleman. It is just possible that Major MacKay was absent from the office when the letter was written. You will note, therefore, that Mr. Bunt is in error when he states that Major MacKay had no information that the Salvation Army had been asked to nominate a teacher. Not only was Major MacKay asked to express an opinion on the matter, but he was requested also to consult the Indian agent.

I am personally in agreement with Mr. Bunt when he states that he should have been consulted before the Army was asked to nominate a teacher. In this connection I am fully persuaded that when Mr. Phelan wrote to Major MacKay on July 21st he did so with the feeling that Major MacKay would not only consult the Indian agent but the other parties, including Mr. Bunt, interested in the nomination of the teacher and in the operation of the school. These misunderstandings do arise, regardless of the care exercised from time to time, and we do attempt to exercise the utmost care in dealing with these somewhat delicate matters. We are, as you know, working with a very limited staff here, as the result of enlistments, and Major MacKay has been without even a clerk for the last six months.

In my judgment it would be very unwise for us to accept the nomination of a teacher by the United Church in this case. The Salvation Army have been requested to nominate a teacher and have replied that the necessary steps to do so have been taken by them and that the name and qualifications of the teacher will be sent forward in due course. Indeed, it is just possible that a teacher, nominated by the Salvation Army has already incurred expenses in making ready to take up this position at Kitselas. I feel confident we shall experience the utmost difficulty in securing teachers for the vacant positions at our Indian day schools. Consequently, Miss Pearson will experience no difficulty whatever in securing a position.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a letter I have received today, from Adjutant Richard Boyes, of the Salvation Army, who was recently appointed as teacher at the Kitselas Indian Day School.

I may say that Brigadier Gillingham was at the office in October and advised that he had requested Boyes to be at Kitselas not later than the 25th of October. This, I believe, was done after he had received a letter from Mr. Boyes giving his reasons for thinking it unwise for him to accept the position. The attached letter is the first intimation I have had of the nature of Mr. Boyes illness.

Personally, I think the Salvation Army should be asked to nominate another teacher. The mail services between here and Alaska, headquarters of Brig. Gillingham, are such that I would recommend the Department contacting Salvation Army Headquarters at Toronto, in this matter.

Yours faithfully,

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to the appointment of Adjutant Richard Boyes as teacher of the Kitselas Indian Day School. In view of his physical condition I agree with you that it would be undesirable to insist on his taking charge of the school. I am writing to this effect to the head office of the Salvation Army in Toronto.

The Department acted on the assumption that Adjutant Boyes would take charge and, as a result, his cheque for October salary was issued and sent to him at Copper River, B.C. I am writing to the Postmaster at that point with a view to having the cheque returned. You might, however, mention the matter to Brigadier Gillingham so that he can have the cheque returned if, by any chance, it has been forwarded to Adjutant Boyes.

Re: Kitselas School.

Captain E. L. Bailey was transferred to Canyon City. Unfortunately, she did not arrive at the Iaas in time to reach Canyon City while navigation was open.

In my letter of November 31st, I stated: "If the transfer is approved, it will be necessary to take quick action so Miss Bailey can be transported to Canyon City before the river freezes over." On December 11th I received word from the Commissioner that the transfer was approved. We wired Miss Bailey and Canyon City for boats to meet her. She left here on the first boat going to the Iaas, December 17th, arriving at Lincoln on the 18th, to find that the river had completely frozen over the day before.

It is not within my province to criticize the Department, and it is not my intention to do so, but I cannot refrain from pointing out the fact that when all matters have to go through the Vancouver office, considerable delay and inconvenience is caused.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir;

I have just received the amount equal to bonus for June quarter from the Treas. of the Methodist Missionary Society.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Char M. MacKinnon
Teacher
Ottawa, August 20th, 1925.

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 12th instant, I beg to say that payment of bonus to teachers in Indian day schools was discontinued from March 31st, last. Previous to that date you were paid salary for the academic year at the rate of $800 and bonus at the rate of $150, or a total of $950 for the ten teaching months. The cheque for your salary was sent to the Treasurer of the Methodist Missionary Society, and the bonus cheque was sent direct to you.

Owing to the discontinuance of the bonus, your salary was increased from $800 to $950 from April 1st, last, and payment at this rate was made for the June quarter, and a cheque for $265 was forwarded to the Treasurer of the Methodist Missionary Society. You will receive this amount from him, and you will note that you are now being paid at the same rate as when you were allowed bonus.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Chas. M. MacKinnon, Esq.,
Vanarsdol,

In reply to your letter of the 12th of February regarding the employment of D. A. Burnett as substitute teacher of the Kitselas Indian Day School during the illness of Mr. C. A. MacKinnon, I would state that Mr. MacKinnon being advised that he was suffering from a disease necessitating surgical treatment in Vancouver, he hurriedly left Kitselas and not feeling justified in leaving the school without a teacher, engaged the services of Mr. Burnett, who is a high school graduate, and paid him the sum of $57, being 19 days at $3.00 per day - from January 25th to February 13th.

Mr. MacKinnon has applied for a refund of the amount. In view of the circumstances and the fact that he was obliged to seek a specialist's advice at considerable expense I would recommend favourable consideration of his request. He is an old man, owing to which fact he is obliged to relinquish the school work at the end of the June quarter, and any consideration which can be shown will be very helpful to him.

Sir:-

I beg to confirm my telegram of the 20th relative to the total loss by fire of the Kitselas Indian Day School and teacher's residence.

On receipt of word respecting the fire, I visited Kitselas and found that the conflagration had been caused by an overheated stove. The fire took place at night when the teacher was sleeping and although upon awakening he did his best to subdue the flames the fire had already gained too much headway.

The Indians gave every assistance possible. Everything was destroyed including the teacher's personal effects.

As stated in my wire temporary arrangements were made to carry on the school in the United Church building as soon as possible. The church authorities however, may not care to prolong the present arrangement and there is no other building that can be used for the purpose. As the teacher is without accommodation some assistance should be given towards securing a room in the village, and I would suggest that $10. per month be allowed for this purpose.

I would again express the opinion that fire extinguishers should be supplied for these out-of-the-way school buildings where water pressure is not available as by this means fire may sometimes be held in check until assistance arrives.

The Indians did everything possible in fighting the fire and supplied the teacher with necessary clothing as he escaped from the building in his night attire, all his other belongings having been
destroyed.

Necessary supplies only, as authorized by the Department, are being purchased locally. A further requisition however will be forwarded for school desks as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, February 1, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, reporting the total loss by fire of the Kitselas Indian day school building and teacher's residence, which was caused by an overheated stove. The arrangements made to carry on the work have been noted. It is hoped that the Church authorities will agree to the work being carried on in the church, as it will not be possible during the ensuing fiscal year to provide the expenditure required in the erection of a new school and residence. It is noted that you are forwarding a requisition for the school desks required, and this will receive consideration.

Regarding the providing of some assistance towards the cost of a room for the teacher's use in the village, I have to say that the Department has never paid for services of this nature. Our Estimates for next year have been cut to such an extent that we could not, in any event, pay the cost of a room for the teacher's use. It will be necessary for you to limit, to the lowest possible point, all expenses in arranging for suitable classroom accommodation. If the church authorities will not agree to the use of their building during the next school year, it may be necessary to discontinue teaching activity at this point.

Your obedient servant,

EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM MR. H.T. ALLEN TO REV. A. BARNETT, DATED JAN. 23RD, 1935.

"Supplementing the telegram of Jan. 20th re the Vansardol fire.

I heard about it just after dinner on Wednesday the 16th, word having been brought down by Paul Mason. He stated that Percy Gladstone needed immediate medical care, and I made immediate preparations to take Dr. Mills by speeder. But there was none in town, so eventually I had to walk against that winter wind.

I found P.C. in bed at McKenzie's. He was still a bit weak but had gotten over a chill from exposure that night. He stated that the first sign of fire was the smoke that awakened him about 12:30 a.m. (not 1:30 a.m.) only an hour or so after returning from basketball. At that time the fire in the heater was diminishing. On coming down he saw smoke issuing from the V-joint cedar lining just to the north of the front entrance. He smashed the wall in with an axe and it immediately burst into flame. Seeing that it was beyond control even by this time, he hurried upstairs to rescue some effects. So strong was the smoke by this time, that it almost overpowered him, as he drew in a breath. He managed to save the register of the school which he had brought into the living quarters, and then went out and collapsed in the snow about 30 yards from the house in the direction of the river. He had on only his pajamas, which was his only article saved from the fire. He must have stayed there 15-20 minutes and was picked up by Eddie Peak, one of the village Indians, as he came to fight the fire. They rescued only the school table. Percy came down to us on Thursday and is leaving tonight. The poor boy feels he has nowhere to go now nor a place to call his own, so we just let him stay as long as he wanted.

Mr. Collison was up, and thinks new buildings ought to be erected more suitable than the last. He also suggests use of the church. I think there ought to be some rental, as there is the wear and tear on the building at least. The Salvation Army were willing to let him use their hall until a new school etc. was built. The Indians gave him almost a complete outfit, suit, socks, shirts and underwear. We had a few things for him and there were some other articles given us for him. He expects to start teaching on Wednesday of this week.

Percy is not sure how the fire started. It seemed to be from the chimney at the point where the stovepipe enters the brick, and to have spread from there. I have done what I could to look after everything there and I trust there will be greater appreciation among the people of the school etc. They asked to have Percy retained as the teacher."

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to the payment of a rental for the use of the church building at Kitselas during the period it is occupied for day school purposes.

Dear Sir,

I beg to advise you that an amount of approximately $4,500 is available for the building of a new Day School at Kitselas, Skeena River Agency.

I understand that accommodation is required for 24 children. Under separate cover I am sending you a blue print copy of a plan which it is thought would be suitable for this work, with the exception that the classroom will require to be reduced in length by eight feet, as the classroom accommodation in the plan provides for 40.

The plan also shows a basement full size of the building and this of course may not be advisable as same would depend to a great extent on the location. The matter of the basement will be left to your discretion, keeping in mind that the total cost of the building must not exceed the amount mentioned.

Mr. William Little of Terrace, B. C. may be employed as Foreman Carpenter for this building, and the lumber is to be purchased from Vancroft Lumber Company of Vancroft, and the George Little Lumber Co., of Terrace, B. C. The hardware and paint should be purchased from Ed. Kenney Ltd., Terrace, B. C., and the cement from Albert and McCaffery, Prince Rupert, B. C.

An Encumbrance Certificate for the above mentioned amount will be sent to you, and the number of this E.R. should be indicated on all accounts, vouchers, etc. in connection with the work.

Yours very truly,

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B. C.

September 21, 1936.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of the Department's letter 168-20-5 dated August 18th last, with enclosures of four copies of plans of the proposed Day School and Residence for the Kitselas Reserve.

No specifications were received, however these are being taken off the blue print by, and the immediate construction of the building has been arranged for, with Mr. William Little, Foreman Carpenter, nominated by the Department.

It is noted that the classroom is to be reduced in length by about eight feet, and any other alterations considered necessary may be carried out to adapt the plan to the local requirements.

An Encumbrance Certificate in the sum of $4,500.00 has also been received, and it is understood from the Department's letter quoted above that the total cost of the building is not to exceed this amount.

It is not clear whether the cost of the furniture for the residence, and of the equipment for the classroom, is included in the above sum of $4,500.00, and I shall be glad to have your instructions on this point at the earliest possible opportunity.

In the event of the Department taking over the Lakeside Hatchery there will become available a McClary hot air furnace in good condition and suitable for the heating of the classroom and the teacher's residence. Bathroom fixtures will also be available, as well as a fairly good kitchen cookstove, sink, and other plain furniture for the residence.

I would request that the Department forward immediately an accountable cheque for the sum of $1,000.00 to meet current expenses in connection with this building.

Your obedient servant,

W. E. Collison,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, October 19, 1936.

Dear Sir:

In further reference to your letter of the 21st ultimo, relative to the construction of a combined day school and teacher's residence on the Kitama Reserve, and with special reference to the furniture for the residence and equipment required for the classroom and heating, I would say that this Department has taken over the buildings and equipment of the Lakelee Hatchery from the Fisheries Department. We understand that the mess-house contains a small quantity of plain furniture, linoleum and a few miscellaneous articles; a good cook stove with hot water boiler and certain other equipment; and that, in the basement, there is a McClary hot air furnace, complete with hot and cold air pipes.

I have therefore to request that, when the building is ready, you will arrange to have the furnace removed from the mess-house at the hatchery and installed in the school building. When the building is ready, you should also remove any furnishings and equipment that would be useful in the residence and school. The Department would pay any costs involved in having the furnace, stove and other furnishings removed to the new school building. It is hoped that there will not be a large expense involved in the transportation of the equipment that is taken from Lakelee to the school.

No doubt, it will be necessary to supply desks for the classroom and equipment for the teacher's living quarters. Please furnish the Department with a list of the desks and other equipment required. Regarding the desks, you should give the size and the number of each size that will be needed.

I may add that Mr. Perry, Assistant Indian Commissioner, Victoria, has been informed that the Department is taking over the buildings and equipment of the hatchery.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert,

Sir:

I also met Mr. William Little at Terrace and conferred with him regarding the work on the new school and teacher's residence for the Kitselas Reserve. Mr. Little has been engaged on other work and informed me that he would not be able to start on the school until some time in October. No specifications were received with the blue print plans of the proposed building and it will be necessary to have these prepared before the work commences.

Before leaving Kitselas, I went over the school plans again with Mr. Little and together with Capt. Barry decided upon a new location for the building, which will be more suitable than the old one.

Sir:

I beg to forward my report as follows for the month of October.

On the 19th instant, I visited Terrace and Kitselas Reserves, in connection with the erection of the new Day school and teacher's residence at the latter place. Whilst most of the building material is already on the ground and excavation for the basement completed, the actual construction of the building has been delayed on account of wet and stormy weather, which has prevailed during most of the month. The foreman-carpenter put in charge by the Department is an elderly person and Indian labour is employed.

E.R.646, Aug.18-36

I beg to transmit herewith, vouchers 7888 and 7899 with attached accounts for material for the Kitselas Indian Day School.

The account of messrs Mitchell & Currie of Prince Rupert includes windows, doors, stair casing, and all inside finishings which were made up by the firm all ready to put into place at the school thus saving extra cost in wages at Kitselas.

New building plans and specifications for quantities were also prepared by the firm for which a charge of $40.00 is made.

Also during my absence on the Queen Charlotte Islands in January, Mr. Mitchell was requested to supervise the work for which a charge of $35.00 has been made. I consider the account reasonable for the services rendered.

On account of the cold weather and deep snow it was necessary to temporary suspend work on the building until conditions are more favorable. Every effort will be made to finish the work before the end of March.

I am enclosing herewith statement of expenditures in connection with the construction of the new school at Kitselas reserve, up to the end of the fiscal year 1936-37, amounting to $4,120.60, also showing a credit balance of $579.40.

As it was necessary that this work should be proceeded with without interruption, I authorized Mr. Little, to carry on up to April 15th, but he was informed that his wages for that period could not be paid until the Department had authorized the new appropriation.

During a visit to the Kitselas reserve last week I inspected the building and found that the following still remains to be done before the building is completed and ready for use:

- Finishing of interior and kalsomining classroom and living quarters.
- Painting of exterior of building and shingles.
- Finishing of brick chimney.
- Putting in bathroom fixtures.
- Service water tank for kitchen and bathroom supply.
- Digging well for water pipe, pump and piping.
- Two outside toilets, one for school and one for residence.

These extras will cost approximately $856.00 and I shall be glad if this amount is made available in order to complete the work.
It will be seen that the cost of the building exclusive of furnishings, has exceeded the original estimate. This is partly due to the fact that a part cement basement called for in the plans was not provided for, and partly to the slowness of the work most of which had to be undertaken during the winter months. notwithstanding, the work has been well done and the building when completed will be one of the best of its kind in the agency.

The following furnishings will be required for the classroom and teacher's residence:

**Classroom**
- Blackboard 30 x 4 feet.
- Book cupboard
- Window blinds
- Teacher's desk and chair
- 6 single desks
- 1 lamp

**Residence**
- Crockery & kitchen ware
- Table for living room
- 1 occasional chair
- Blinds for windows.

Prices and specifications for the above will be forwarded later.

Other articles and furniture have been provided from the Lakelse hatchery buildings including one furnace for central heating of school and kitchen range, linoleum, bathroom fixtures etc., which items very considerably cut down the cost of furnishings.

As it will probably be June before the painting can be done it will be advisable to defer the opening until September.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

We have just received cheque from the Dept. of Finance for $650 for team hauling done by us for the Vancouver Indian school in Dec. 1936. We were advised by the man in charge of work that he would need our team again shortly, but as the supplies he expected did not arrive we presented our bill some time in February. Early in March we hauled the expected supplies 2 days work $3.50, and we presented total bill of $4.50 to the Prince Rupert agent, reminding him the previous bill had not been paid. These bills were made in quadruplicate as required. We have not received our $650.

Why all this delay? We are not in the transfer business. We are ordinary working men, loggers, and we left our work at an inconvenience to do this hauling because other teams were not easily available. You have had other men working on the building who get their pay regularly. Why discriminate against us? We are in no position to advance credit to the Dept. of Indian Affairs. We have to buy hay at 27¢ per ton and oats at 3.5¢ per bushel, and pay our men wages, to do this work for you. It may be a small sum, but we need every cent we make, and it is extremely annoying.

We hesitate to believe that this dilatory method of paying your debts can be the regular policy of your Dept., and are inclined to believe it is due to some neglect or irregularity in your local agent. We have already billed him twice, and are therefore writing to you.

Yours truly,

Doney & Jordan

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the construction of a new school on the Kitselas Reserve.

It is regretted that this work was not completed before the end of March, last. The appropriation in which the expenditure for this school was provided has now lapsed and no provision was made in our appropriation for the current fiscal year for additional funds.

You mentioned in your letter that the following items are unfinished:

(1) Finishing of interior and kalsomining classroom and living quarters.

(2) Painting of exterior of building and shingles.

(3) Finishing of brick chimney.

(4) Putting in bathroom fixtures.

(5) Service water tank for kitchen and bathroom supply.

(6) Digging well for water pipe, pump and piping.

On reviewing the copy of the plan sent to you for this building, it is noted that no provision was made for a bathroom. Please let me know why you consider it necessary to place in this building items 4 and 5 in view of the fact

W. E. Collison, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Prince Rupert, B. C.
Sir:-

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 23th ultm. relative to the Niselas Indian Bay School, which arrived at this office during my absence in the south.

With regard to the delay in completing the building I would state that the work was not started until late in October owing to the fact that the carpenter appointed by the Department to put up the school was employed on other work at the time. Added to this, a severe winter made it necessary to close the work down for a time making it impossible to finish the building by the end of the fiscal year.

It is to be regretted that the cost has exceeded the original appropriation of $4500.00 which no doubt is due to the extra expense of putting in a cement foundation and basement.

In this connection I would point out that on my recommendation the cement work called for in the plans was considerably curtailed, thereby saving further expenditure.

(1) With regard to item 1 in your letter covering kalsomining of the interior in the classroom and teacher's residence which will cost in the neighborhood of $35.00. This work can be deferred till next year.

(2) With respect to the painting of the exterior of the school and shingles, this must be done to preserve the building and prevent the boards from warping and cracking.

The paint for this purpose has already been purchased and paid for under vouchers numbers 7945 and 7984 in favor of M.T.Kenney Ltd., leaving the labor only to be provided for. This will cost approximately - $75.00.
2.

(3) Finishing the brick chimney on the outside of the building. This must be done before another winter sets in, otherwise the bricks will deteriorate. Cost approximately $10.00

(4) Installing bathroom fixtures etc. The small addition on the plans intended for a summer kitchen which was unnecessary, has been utilized as a bathroom. The bath and other fixtures were brought from the dismantled lakeview hatchery building, authorized by the Department in letter dated Oct. 29th 1936.

The bathroom will prove of the greatest convenience, especially in the case of a woman teacher, as however, the cost of the building has already exceeded the appropriation, I would suggest that the bath and basin only be installed at present, and an outside toilet provided. This would do away with the necessity of purchasing and installing a service tank and kitchen hot water boiler and other fittings. The cost of putting in the bath and wash basin with drain pipe will be approximately $45.00

(5) Already answered.

(6) It will be necessary to have a well dug and a suitable pump installed for domestic use and fire protection. There is no running water nearby. Probable cost of pump (No. 1059 McLennan, McGeely Ltd., Vancouver) including freight $35.00, labor and material $20.00. Total $55.

Sir,

I beg to report as follows for the months of April and May:

I was able, however, on my way back to visit the Kitselas reserve, and inspect progress of the work on the new school building.

It is hoped the necessary funds will be authorized to complete the building before next school term.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant with reference to the Kitselas Indian Day School.

Sir:

Referring to the Department's letters dated April 28th and June 1st last, authorizing expenditures to furnish the Kitselas Indian Day school, I beg to enclose herewith, returns of labor amounting to $272.50; and accounts for material amounting to $14.72, making a total of $287.22 for work done as follows:

- Painting exterior of shingles of school
- Finishing brick chimney
- Installing bath, wash-basin and drain pipe authorized in official letter No.168-20-5, June 1st.$185.00.

Construction of outside toilets, (1 double for school

- Painting; and digging pits authorized in official letter No.168-20-5, April 28th.$75.00

Material, Albert & McCaffery, cement etc. $3.17
E.T.Kenney Ltd., hardware $11.55 $14.52

Removing school desks from old church to new building and putting same on strips.
Taking down blackboard and replacing same in new school. $12.50

$287.22

On account of continued wet weather during the past summer, the work of painting the school was held up and has cost more than the original estimate. There not being sufficient funds, it was not possible to have the well dug.

Further examination showed that it would be necessary to sink to a depth of 40 feet before reaching water. This will cost $2.50 per foot for digging and casing, bringing the total cost of sinking the well to approximately $100.00, this does not include the cost of a pump which will be another $30.

I would recommend that this work be done as soon as possible as a protection against fire hazard, the nearest well
well being about three hundred yards distant from the school.

The school and residence are now completed and in use. Progress of the work on the building was slow at times owing largely to severe weather conditions, and other difficulties.

The work, however, was well and satisfactorily carried out by Mr. Little and the building as it stands is well worth the money expended.

Yours faithfully,

Indian Agent

WEC/JJ

I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Anfield's letter of March 13th in connection with the proposed provision of telephone facilities at the Kitselas Indian Day School. I have discussed this matter with District School Inspector Davey who agrees with the Agent that the circumstances are such that an expenditure for the installation and rental of a telephone is warranted.

You will note that the Salvation Army is prepared to pay 50% of the monthly rental, the Department to pay the other $1.50 each month and installation costs amounting to approximately $25.00. In view of the circumstances I concur in Mr. Anfield's recommendation and would ask the Department to approve the installation.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
At Kitselas we have a Day School with an average attendance of between 12 and 15. There are about 45 people living in the village all told. Access to this village is difficult at any time. Present modes of travel to Kitselas are by railroad from Prince Rupert to Kitselas and to walk up the track about 3 miles to the Indian village; the other way is by road from Terrace to Copper ferry and to walk up the track about 5 miles.

The teacher at Kitselas is an unmarried Salvation Army Officer and she has been a bit disturbed at having to live alone without any means of communication with the outside. Recently this village came down with a very serious outbreak of flu and as the ferry service was frozen out, it was some time before we received word of conditions in the village. Arrangements were made at once to send a Doctor into these people and Dr. Macdonald sent a Field Nurse up there for a few days this week-end.

It is recommended that a telephone be placed in this village so that a direct communication can be had with the exchange at Terrace. The Dominion Government Telegraph Service have been approached and have agreed to put this line in provided that the village people supply the poles and look after the line men as to board and room for 3 days. I have consulted with Brigadier Gillingham of the Salvation Army and he authorizes me to state that his organization will pay 50% of the monthly rental of $3.00 for the phone, if and when installed. It is, therefore, recommended

(1) that the Department make available a sum of $25.00 for installation costs.
(2) that the Department authorize the installation of this phone by the Dominion Government Telegraph Service at a monthly rental of $3.00 - 50% to be paid by the Salvation Army.
I have consulted Dr. Macdonald, the Agency Medical Officer, regarding this matter and he is of the opinion that the phone would prove of real value in connection with Health Services at this village. I attach herewith contract forms forwarded to this office by the Dominion Government Telegraph Service.

Your instructions will be appreciated.

F. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Amfield:

We herewith submit our report on the furnace at the Indian School, Kitselas, B. C., as follows:

1. On being dismantled, this furnace was found to be badly burned out and beyond repair.
2. There was found to be a shortage of cold air return to the furnace which tended to slow down the warm air circulation. This let the furnace get too hot that it could easily have set fire to the building and yet insufficient heat was getting into the school.
3. The warm and cold air ducts were actually reversed from the correct method. The warm air was coming up along the side of the buildings with the windows and the cold air the opposite side. This procedure should be exactly the reverse for proper efficiency.

We strongly recommend to balance up the cold air and install one new warm air register, as the present set-up would, in all probability, burn out a new furnace the first winter, should the Department decide to install one.

The school teachers residence would appear to be in good shape. Trusting we may be of further service to you, we remain,

Yours very truly,
THOM SHEET METAL LTD.

Manager.

Extract from Inspector Barry's report on the Kitselas Indian day school visited on May 30, 1939.

Perfectly splendid Indian art work has been done by the children since my last visit, and many of my own suggestions followed by Mrs. Wilson. May I recommend that the school be given a grant of $100.00 per year to cover the following:

(a) The provision of a set of simple manual training tools so that some half dozen boys might be taught carpentry by Mr. Wilson.

(b) The purchase of suitable lumber for the construction of two work benches, cupboard for tools, and the later construction of display boards, tables, and bookcases etc. for the school.

One of the halls not now used by the children would make a very satisfactory if small manual training shop.

The sum of $50.00 should cover items (a) and (b) and I would suggest that the remaining $50.00 be used to

(c) Pay an Indian woman, Mrs. Sam Kennedy, to instruct the girls in basket and mat weaving twice a week from October to April inclusive.

(d) Purchase the material needed for making the baskets and mats suggested in the above paragraph (c).

I understand that Mrs. Sam Kennedy is good in this type of work. She might well be given fifty cents for each lesson of an hour or so, or $1.00 per week while the work was being carried on. It has been found in other parts of the Province that two lessons a week, each of an hour or so, are better than one lesson taking the whole afternoon. The children can practise the work or continue it on the other afternoons. In any case the teacher must take charge at all times. The boys would of course be working at the suggested manual instruction while the girls were being instructed by Mrs. Kennedy.
I have asked the teacher in any case to devote the mornings to the strictly academic work of the school, and the afternoons to all those subjects suggested by Mr. Hoey - singing, arts and crafts, sewing, vocational work and manual training, physical training and games etc. Health is now being taught and considerable success achieved in sewing.

(Sgd.) Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

In the covering letter from Inspector Mackay dated June 13 he wrote as follows:

I would call attention to his recommendation that an annual expenditure of £100.00 be made at this school, of which £50.00 is to be used in the purchase of tools and lumber for manual training, and £50.00 with which to engage an Indian instructress for Indian arts and purchase of necessary material.

I would recommend approval of these expenditures for the current fiscal year.

(Sgd.) D.M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir,

I again write to make application for a School Grant for the Indian school at Kitwining, on the Upper Skeena; this is the third time I have made application, but why no grant has been given I have not heard.

Your last letter to me on this subject was dated June 11, 1899, No. 201. J.S. The "School Returns" have been duly sent in as you suggested, for the last two winters, but without result.

The last application was sent through your Agent at Hazelton, and reported on by him.

The school has been open regularly during the residence of the people since 1889.

Hoping this will receive the favourable consideration of your department,

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

(Rev) Alfred T. Price

As you may have heard Rev. A.E. Price is leaving our Gitwangak Mission next September for a year in England and may not return to this station.

It is, therefore, necessary for me to make as soon as possible some arrangement for a teacher. I wish to secure a competent white teacher but the Day School Grant is only $400, while most of the other schools receive $500. I wish to point out to the Department:

1. The Department has for years been using our school building without paying us a cent of rent.

2. The expense of bringing a qualified teacher from Vancouver to Gitwangak is about $50, according to the state of the Skeena river. The Department has never to my knowledge paid this.

3. Without a married missionary resident at Gitwangak no white woman teacher could live alone in the Indian village as there are no other white people with whom to live. We must, therefore, have a white male teacher this winter.

4. A white male teacher cannot be obtained for $400 a year. We could not live on this.

Under all these circumstances I feel fully justified in asking for at least the standard salary of $500, and I think to cover the
the travelling expenses, as well as the upkeep of the building and such like demands upon our Funds the Department should allow us a rental for our school-house.

I should like to know soon whether I can count upon this increased Grant so that I may have time to secure a well qualified teacher by September. I can assure the Department that it is most difficult to secure proper teachers and the Church has in most cases to add greatly to what the Government allows in the way of salary.

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

(Signed) F. H. Du Vernet

In reply I beg to say that when I questioned the Rev. A.B. Price, the Missionary in charge, as to why a new teacher secured in the fall invariably left the following spring, he replied that the small grant was the chief reason. The Church does not assist with any grant, and as he has to pay traveling expenses of teacher from Vancouver to Kitwangah, and then forty dollars a month salary, he could not keep one longer. But to fill up the school days his son (a young boy), and other unqualified persons, taught when they were unable to pay a teacher. The last teacher was but poorly qualified for the work, but he said it was the best he could do with the present grant. I told him I was not satisfied with the way the school was being conducted.

Mr. Price informed me that he would be leaving the place in September (next month) and so, some one else would look for a teacher for the fall of 1911. I think that, with a new Missionary in charge, the school will have a better chance.

I think it would be an improvement if the Missionaries or Church authorities were required to notify the Department, when they dismiss or change teachers in any of the schools receiving Government grants.

Adverting to my letter dated September 10th 1921 and to yours of above mentioned date regarding the payment of salary for the two holiday months, viz: July and August 1921, to Miss Kemp, formerly teacher at the Kitwanga Indian Day School, I submit for your further consideration the following facts regarding Miss Kemp from which you will understand my reason for again bringing this matter before you.

Two other resignations of Teachers have occurred during this year in this Agency, and in each case resignation was made at the end of September 1921, and, in only one case was notification sent to me at the close of the School Year 1920-21, and no such consideration was shown for the work of the Department as in the case of Miss Kemp and her resignation.

Miss Kemp informed me, during my visit to Kitwanga in June that she intended resigning her position at the end of the School year, but I received no formal written notice from her until I requested her to do so in a letter dated August 15th. Mr Cairns told me that Miss Kemp had been in the employ of the Department as teacher for over 10 years and had done very good work assisting the women in cases of sickness where a woman's attention is imperative. In her resignation Miss Kemp expressed her willingness to continue to do what she could in cases of sickness amongst the women and in assisting in the dispensing of medicines to her old pupils.

In reply I beg to say that the school year ends on June 30th, and she was paid in full to that date. If she had taught during the month of September she would only have been entitled to payment for the number of days she actually taught during the month.

The Department has adopted the method of paying teachers who are in continuous service the full quarter's salary for September, but, in reality, they are not legally entitled to this amount. Each school year begins on September 1st and ends the following June 30th. Summer holidays are not taken into account in the payment of teachers salaries. In some cases the teachers have delayed forwarding their resignations until after they have been paid their full quarterly salary and, by so doing, they have been paid more than the amount which they earned.

However, in view of Miss Kemp's long service and owing to the fact that during the past summer she did a certain amount of work on the reserve, the Department has decided to allow her the full quarter's salary, a cheque for which amount is being forwarded to you under separate cover. She will also be allowed bonus for the month of September, the same as allowed the teachers in other Indian day schools.

The action taken in allowing payment in this instance is not to form a precedent for future cases of a similar nature.

Yours obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

E. Hyde, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hazelton,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. G. H. BARRY, INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS, DATED MAY 22, 1933, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE KITWANGA INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

The school is very far from being a success. The room is a little less untidy and dusty than when I inspected this school in October, 1931. I am certainly far from satisfied with conditions here.

As far as school work is to be considered, there would not appear to me to be much use carrying on this school. No suggestions that I could make would help much, as the teacher is not adapted to this sort of work. The children find it very hard to understand his way of speaking, which is mainly due to a peculiar French accent. I doubt that this man has any general command of the English language. The school leaves much to be desired in the way of cleanliness. No one could possibly be interested in the school as conducted at present; though I think the teacher is doing his best to make things a little better.

The attendance is so very poor in this school that I should like to suggest to the Department the consideration of closing the school as a matter of economy. It will never be a success with this teacher, who is the local Missionary. With a trained teacher the school might be worked up during several years till it was of some use to the people. At present the parents are not very interested in the school. I am quite in sympathy with the Indians, as I can see no reason why any child should want to attend such a dismal place. The teacher is not trained for this sort of work.

The school is not in a satisfactory condition. As I have recommended above that the Department consider closing this school, I would ask that a check be kept on the reports of attendance during the school year starting in September, 1933. I would ask that the Indian Agent be asked for a report on this school early in 1934, as I shall not be able to visit there this year if I am to inspect schools not visited this last year. Should the Indian Agent's report be as poor as this present one, I should recommend the closing of the school to save the salary being paid to the missionary now, as well as the other expenses of the school.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of Sept. 14th, 1932 re Inspector's Report on Indian Day School at Kitwanga.

I can only first of all say that the report was an extreme surprise to me. Will you allow me to reply to some of the criticisms of the Inspector?

There is no teacher with such experience in teaching native children in this and other countries as Mr. Flores has had. He has been the principal of a native school in Arabia with 300 pupils and won the commendation of all in authority. He is a more than ordinarily cultured man, not only speaking French, Spanish, Italian, Arabic and English, but is able to, and has taught at times all these languages.

The statement that it is useless to carry on the school under Mr. Flores is completely unsound. I spent half a day in the school yesterday and listened to the exercises of the children, and having been at one time a teacher myself, I am in a position to form something of an accurate opinion of the work done, and can unreservedly say that the work was above the average. I noticed in particular that certain pupils, who up until now have been in residence in an Edmonton boarding school for natives, but are at present in this school, did not make as good a showing as the pupils who have never been in any other school except the Kitwanga school.

Mr. Barry unfortunately visits a number of the Indian schools at a time when many of the families are off the reservations, either fishing or trapping, or hunting. It so happened when he last visited Kitwanga, many of the families were away. Had he visited this school a month earlier, he would have found a full school.

Yesterday, when again several families were away, there were yet 18 pupils in the school. There are 26 on the school roll. When the inspector was here there were only four at school, and these were nearly every child then in the village.
He had practically no opportunity of judging the work accomplished, nor did he inquire into the methods.

Wherever I visit Indian reservations, if there is any complaint about teachers, the Indians at once let me hear all about their complaints. Such complaints have never been made by the parents of Kitwanga. Before this, there is not a reservation in this diocese with which I have anything to do, where there is such harmony on the part of all as there is here, this was not the case before Mr. Flores took charge.

While I know the department expects the teacher paid by it to be efficient as a teacher, I still believe the department would be pleased to know that he was also a good moral and religious influence in the community. Mr. Flores is eminently that.

Something can be done with paint to make the school look brighter; this we are quite willing to do. As for the lack of cleanliness to which Mr. Barry refers, I can only say that I am assured that the school has always been swept out twice a day and sometimes oftener. That is a matter however which can be easily righted.

As to Mr. Flores' French accent, I can only say that he is not French, but he has an accent. I heard him give an address to the natives this other night, and I am sure he was clearly understood by everyone who understood English at all, and in listening to him teaching yesterday, there was not the slightest difficulty along that line.

Mr. Barry himself has his limitations. His brusque manner has been complained of to me by several teachers, the children being worried by it and not able to show their best work. I am also convinced that he is unfairly prejudiced against Mr. Flores, whom I consider one of our finest and most efficient men.

I would like you to write to the very efficient and level-headed Indian agent at Hazelton, asking his opinion about school matters in Kitwanga. He is interested in Mr. Flores and is ready to help him in every possible way he can.

I consider it would be a real misfortune if any change were made in the Indian day school at Kitwanga.

Trusting that you will give weight to the opinion of one who has for many years had a vital interest in the natives of Northern B.C., both as to their material, moral and spiritual welfare, and who would hesitate to recommend anything which would not be a real help in such things.

Awaiting a favorable reply,

I am,

Yours faithfully,

Bishop of Caledonia.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of October 24th regarding the report of School Inspector Barry with reference to the Rev. Henry Flores, Indian Day School Teacher at Kitwanga.

After careful perusal of Inspector Barry's report on this school, may I be permitted to say that, in all fairness to Mr. Flores, conditions were very unfavourable on the day of inspection. Only four very young pupils were then in attendance; the majority having gone with their parents to the coast canneries. Naturally the teacher was greatly embarrassed and the four little children were nervous at the prospect of a school examination which resulted in the examination being a partial failure. Therefore Inspector Barry was unable to see if any progress had been made since his previous visit on October 19th, 1931.

When Mr. Flores took over this school no doubt the children found that his English was difficult to understand, the cause of same being that the children who attended this school were all young and had no knowledge of English prior to their admittance. Quite a number of the older children of the village were in the Edmonton Residential School, some of whom now attend the Kitwanga School.

Since Inspector Barry's inspection of this school I have made several visits and spent some time with Mr. Flores in going through each grade and I am pleased to say a great improvement is noticed when all the children are in attendance. These visits will be continued during the winter and reports made accordingly.

Mr. Flores is greatly liked by the Indians of Kitwanga and is doing good work amongst them.

Regarding the cleanliness of the school buildings, a coat of paint inside would considerably add to the cleanliness of same. The floors are often scrubbed.

In conclusion may I say that if Inspector Barry could visit this Agency at a more opportune time of the year - say November or April - I am of opinion that a better report would be submitted by the Inspector on the Kitwanga School.

Dear Mr. Shearman:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 5th ultimo, in which you express a desire to secure specific information with respect to our welfare programme and the relationship of this programme to Indian pupils immediately following the completion of the regular school course.

The departmental circular of January 25, 1937, was an introductory circular, sent out in the hope that it would establish a point of contact between the officials here and the teachers in charge of our Indian day and residential schools. It was our hope, also, that the teachers would reply to the communication, giving us a brief outline of local conditions and the difficulties confronting them. I am glad to be able to state that the majority of the teachers have communicated with us from time to time and have forwarded many helpful suggestions. It was not our intention, nor is it our intention now, to send out these circular letters individually. We have not, at the central office, a staff that would enable us to undertake such a task. In addition to this, Indian agents, under the direction of Indian inspectors, are responsible for departmental administration on the reserves. These men are notified of any changes that may take place in departmental policy from time to time. In the outlying districts, of course, it may be exceedingly difficult for Indian agents to keep in close contact with the teachers in charge of our schools, but the majority of agents attempt to do so.

It is exceedingly difficult to submit a brief summary of the departmental welfare programme. At this date, approximately one-third of the Indian population in Canada are in receipt of relief. This condition is due, in part, to drought conditions in Western Canada, particularly in the province of Saskatchewan, and to the difficulty experienced by Indians in securing trapping and fishing areas free from the competition of white trappers and white fishermen. Last year, however, in addition to the general effort, an appropriation of approximately one million dollars ($1,000,000) was set apart as a special rehabilitation appropriation. This money has been spent in an attempt to clear land, build houses, purchase farm machinery and trapping leases and in an attempt to purchase horses and equipment for Indian pupils who have completed their courses at our schools. It is encouraging to note that, despite prevailing economic conditions, the programme has been, on the whole, very successful. Consideration has also been given to a health programme, designed to restrict and ultimately eradicate the ravages of tuberculosis amongst the members of our Indian ...

Rev. B. Shearman,
Teacher,
Kitwanga Indian Day School,
Kitwanga, B. C.
Indian population. It is our hope that in the estimates of this year an amount of $150,000.00 will be included for this work.

Indian pupils who have obtained a creditable standing on their Entrance Examinations and who are in good physical condition are eligible for departmental tuition grants, which grants enable them to proceed with either the regular high school courses or special vocational courses. A large number of Indian pupils throughout the Dominion take advantage of these tuition grants from year to year. This year, by way of experiment, we have sent a group of girls ranging in age between 16 and 20 to a vocational school at Ste. Anne's, Quebec. At this school these girls will be given a special course in handloom weaving, handicraft work, domestic science, sanitation, etc. Arrangements have also been completed with the Superintendent of National Parks, whereby a group of boys, graduates of our residential schools, will proceed to these parks this spring and take up a two-year course, thus qualifying to become national park rangers. A few months ago, we entered into negotiations with the management of the Canadian National and Canadian Pacific dining car service and with the automobile manufacturers in Canada, in the hope that positions might be secured for a number of Indian boys. In view of the fact, however, that thousands of fully qualified white boys are seeking such positions, our negotiations, while still open, have not proved very successful.

In your letter you refer to a regulation preventing Indian pupils from proceeding with high school studies. I have no knowledge of such regulation. This does not mean, of course, that all Indian pupils who apply for tuition grants succeed in their request. The appropriation for this work is somewhat limited, owing to the steadily multiplying demands for relief allowances. Then, too, it is often difficult to secure for Indian boys and girls accommodation in towns with high school facilities where their conduct and general moral welfare would be under the direct supervision of responsible individuals. I am not at the moment fully convinced that the regular high school course is the course that Indian pupils should be encouraged to proceed with. I am rather inclined to think that they should be encouraged to take courses in diesel engineering, auto mechanics and carpentry work. Boys who take these courses experience less difficulty in securing employment than the boys or girls who have proceeded with the academic course.

The files here do not indicate that you have sent in a request for a tuition grant at any time in recent years. If you have done so, however, and the grant has been refused, I would be glad to be supplied with full particulars.

I notice that it has been the policy of the Department...
Department in the past to allow a certain number of pupils from your district to proceed to the residential school at Edmonton. This matter was carefully reviewed about six months ago and a decision reached that, in future, pupils would not be permitted to attend schools outside the province of British Columbia. It is my understanding that the Indian Commissioner, the Indian Agent and the Principal of the residential school at Edmonton have been informed of this decision.

In circular letter already referred to, I expressed the hope that provision would be made for a certain amount of vocational instruction at all our schools. The requests for vocational supplies reaching the Department from day to day would indicate that a majority of our teachers are making provision for such courses. The Indian pupils appear to be deeply interested in these new assignments.

I have written at considerable length in the hope that I might be able to remove any misunderstanding that may exist in respect to the attempts that are being made by the Department to work out a welfare programme designed to gradually re-establish the Indian population of the Dominion on a satisfactory and self-supporting basis.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.
