Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Kitzwanga Indian Day School, Anglican Church, Babine Agency, which I inspected on September 25th.

Owing to the lack of bridges and road between Hazelton and Kitzwanga this is a difficult school to visit and it was necessary for me to make use of the westbound C.N.R. train on the 25th instant from Hazelton. This involved staying for the night at Kitzwanga school inspecting the next morning and coming on here by the eastbound C.N.R. train early on Saturday morning.

It would appear the school has suffered since my last visit in October 1938 from the fact that the last teacher, the Rev. B. Sheerman now moved to Kitkatla, allowed the standard of academic work to degenerate, and the school to become dirty. The present teacher is highly efficient and has worked hard to clean up the room and desks since she arrived here. I have no doubt that very good work will be done by Mrs Hayhurst. The Indians are much pleased that the change in teachers has been made.

The flag pole which has for some reason been taken down should have a new rope and be replaced in its cement socket. This should certainly not cost more than $5.00 for labour and material.

The steps to the schoolroom, which belongs to the Anglican Church, need immediate repair to make them safe for the children's use. Kalsomine and paint have been purchased for the decoration of the inside of the schoolroom, and the sum of $16 set aside by the Department, though why this was done I do not know as the Anglican Church does appear to be responsible for such work in a general way. I do not remember this matter being taken up in your office. I certainly consider that it would be well for those in the Commissioner's office to have an opportunity to recommend or otherwise expenditures on Indian day schools in B.C.

It would also appear that the matter of the appointment of Mr. John Hayhurst as Dispenser has been taken up with the Department direct through the Acting Indian Agent's action. You will remember that Mr. Hoey wrote about this when Mrs Hayhurst was appointed. I understand that the Right Rev. Bishop did more or less promised Mr. Hayhurst such an appointment when he nominated Mrs. Hayhurst as teacher. I most certainly consider that such matters should be given consideration by you before the Department is asked to make appointments in British Columbia.

There are now some thirty seven children at the school, or at least on the school roll, with a number of small children to come when the parents are all back in the village. Mr. Hayhurst is very good in Manual Training and with the actual academic work of the Primary Grades. You will remember he did this work at Lakelsap, and also acted as Dispenser there. If the Department has any funds for this purpose, and it would appear that there are some available for Mrs Sheerman was paid I believe $15.00 a month, it might be well to appoint Mr. Hayhurst as assistant teacher here.
I explained to Mr. Hayhurst in answer to his questions that the conditions at Kitwanga were not the same as those at the Lakalsap Indian Day School, and that in fact Mrs Hayhurst was fortunate to be permitted to hold a teaching position, for there were very strict Civil Service and Departmental regulations governing the appointment of married women as teachers.

It is only right for me to point out for your information that Mr. Hayhurst is acting as an Anglican missionary at Kitwanga though not of course an ordained man. He did not hold a corresponding position at Greenville (Lakalsap).

The Hayhursts on their own statement did not seek the Kitwanga appointment but were urged to accept it by the Right Rev. Bishop Kix.

Mr. Hayhurst is deaf in one ear. This might prevent his regular employment as a carpenter or machin shop workman, for which trades he is qualified. I suggested that he might attempt to enlist in a technical military unit such as an engineering or searchlight company. He had thought of this himself. His chance of acceptance owing to deafness in one ear is however perhaps slight.

Under the combined circumstances of this case I am prepared to recommend that Mr. John Hayhurst be appointed assistant teacher at Kitwanga, on the understanding that he take charge of the Dispensary and later teach elementary manual training to the older boys. I would suggest that he be paid $20.00 per teaching month for such services.

May I also ask that a sum of $50.00 be included in the 1940-41 Estimates to provide for some simple carpenter tools at this school, and the provision of a small quantity of lumber to make a work bench and some simple articles, and a further $10.00 for sewing materials for the girls.

I hope that the above will assist you and the Department to come to a decision in this matter, and I may say that I am aware that you may not agree with me in the slightest, for a very involved case has been made even worse by the fact that the Acting Indian Agent, Mr. Macdonald, has communicated directly with the Department, and I am not aware at the moment of what his recommendation may have been.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 7th instant and also copies of correspondence relating to the above-noted subject, sent forward therewith.

In view of the salary schedule now in force in B. C., which was approved by you a few weeks ago, I found the recommendation for an increase in the salary of Mrs. Hayhurst somewhat disturbing. In this connection it would appear that a mistake was made when Mrs. Buddrus was granted a monthly allowance as medicine dispenser without first referring the matter to you. However, this decision was not reached by the officials of the Welfare and Training Division but was probably reached by an official who has little, if any, information on the attempts we have been making to bring about a uniform salary schedule at the Indian day schools of British Columbia. The payment of allowances for the dispensing of medicine or for work ordinarily undertaken by officers who are described as field matrons is not a matter that comes within the jurisdiction of this Division. However, I have today discussed the recommendation contained in the last paragraph of your letter with the officer in charge of Personnel. We are agreed that in view of all the circumstances it might be advisable to allow Mrs. Hayhurst the sum of $15.00 a month for the dispensing of drugs. Vouchers covering this amount
might be sent forward from month to month.

I must state, however, that I am rapidly coming to the conclusion that day school teachers should be paid a stated salary and that this salary should be based, not only on their classroom duties and responsibilities, but upon other services that may be performed on the reserve, such as dispensing drugs, the organization of women's clubs, the visiting of homes, etc. In other words, I am disposed to think that our teachers should be classified, not as teachers, but as Welfare and Training officers. These teachers, in my humble judgment, should be permanent Civil Servants and should be employed on our reserves for 12 months in the year, less the regular Civil Service holidays. They should be paid a salary that would attract ambitious young men and women of ability, particularly men, to take up this work. In the meantime and until such a decision is reached, would it be possible for you to work out a salary schedule in British Columbia for next year, which would include remuneration for the services I have enumerated and others that might be added? I appreciate, of course, very fully the limited time at your disposal to undertake such a task, but I do feel that such action would be a substantial step forward toward our ultimate objective.

A word in conclusion - It is noted that the allowance granted Mrs. Buddrus was granted on the recommendation of the Indian agent. It might help us here if Indian agents were definitely instructed to refer such matters to you. The members of our staff are changing so constantly in this critical period that it is exceedingly difficult for recently appointed men to keep abreast of all the decisions and understandings reached a few years ago.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

She is boarding at Kitwanga at present on a very temporary basis and it is urgently necessary that some place of residence be made available to her without delay. To this end I have spoken to Arthur McDames, an Indian who owns a fairly presentable three-room house at Kitwanga which he would rent on a basis of $10 a month. Some interior redecoration would be required and Arthur McDames would agree to this in lieu of rent up to $60 which sum should be sufficient. Re: Kitwanga Day School.

I enclose Indian Agent Boy's letter of the 17th inst., advising that difficulty has arisen following the return of the Anglican missionary, Reverend H. MacKintosh, formerly dispenser for the reserve, and his wife, formerly teacher. The school and residence are owned by the Church and located on a 2.5-acre parcel located in the centre of the reserve. We have been paying the Church a rental for the school for many years, but evidently this did not cover the residence. This created no difficulty so long as we employed the Church officials for duty on the reserve, but this couple had to leave last summer due to Mr. MacKintosh's health. Apparently they are not too well pleased to find the positions had been filled in their absence.

This will indicate the difficulties that arise in the use of church property and employment of missionaries. Under the circumstances, after discussing the matter with Major Davy, the school inspector, I would recommend approval of Mr. Boy's suggestion of renting a house from an Indian and putting it in shape for the teacher's use, the original furnishings being used. If and when Kitwanga opens we can purchase new furnishings for it.

Dear Sir,

There is a matter that I wish to bring before the Indian Department at Ottawa. It is regarding the Day School at Gitwangak.

As you may have heard Rev. A.E. Price is leaving our Gitwangak Mission next September for a year in England and may not return to this station.

It is therefore necessary for me to make as soon as possible some arrangement for a teacher. I wish to secure a competent white teacher but the Day School Grant is only $400, while most of the other schools receive $500. I wish to point out to the Department:

1. The Department has for years been using our school building without paying us a cent of rent.

2. The expense of bringing a qualified teacher from Vancouver to Gitwangak is about $50, according to the state of the Skeena river. The Department has never to my knowledge paid this.

3. Without a married Missionary resident at Gitwangak no white woman teacher could live alone in the Indian village as there are no other white people with whom to live. We must, therefore, have a white male teacher this winter.

4. A white male teacher cannot be obtained for $400, a year. He could not live on this.

Under all these circumstances I feel fully justified in asking for at least the standard salary of $500, and I think to cover the
Travelling expenses as well as the upkeep of the building and such like demands upon our Funds the Department should allow us a rental for our school-house.

I should like to know soon whether I can count upon this increased Grant so that I may have time to secure a well qualified teacher by September. I can assure the Department that it is most difficult to secure proper teachers and the Church has in most cases to add greatly to what the Government allows in the way of salary.

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

F. H. Du Vernet
Bishop of Caledonia

Sir,

I have the honour to state that regarding the subject matter of Departmental letter, dated August 18th, last, and to its concluding part, to ascertain from the Right Rev. F. H. Du Vernet, Bishop of Caledonia, what rent would be asked for the use of the church buildings at Hazelton and Gitwangak, for school purposes, I received a rather late reply upon a second enquiry, and of which I here beg to quote the following,

to wit:-

"Prince Rupert, March 2, 1917.

"R. E. Loring,
Indian Agent, Hazelton, B.C.

"Dear Sir,-

"I am in receipt of your letter of the 23rd ult., dealing with a letter of mine of Aug. 3rd, 1916 in regard to the Hazelton and Gitwangak school buildings. I am glad to learn that the Indian Department has noted for future consideration the matter of building a new school house at Gitwangak and draw your attention to the fact that the Department has for years past been making use of our building without allowing rent or keeping it in repair."

"In reply to your closing words in which you say: 'I am requested to ascertain what rent per month would be asked for the church (school) buildings at Hazelton and Kitwanga.' I wish to answer that after consultation with members of our Church committee we have decided that Eight ($8.) Dollars a month for each school would be a fair rental, it being understood clearly that this was for the use of the building during school hours.

"Further as on August 3rd, 1916 I notified the Department regarding the use of these buildings I consider that rent is due from the beginning of the school year last September.

"The item of insurance, the risk from fire, wear and tear on the building &c. have all to be taken into account in fixing a fair rental., etc."

The foregoing respectfully submitting for the Department's consideration,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I have forwarded your letter of July 27th, to Archdeacon Collinson and asked him to explain the whole matter to Jonathan Mercer.

For the past ten years I have been working steadily towards the new policy. The Indian Department becoming entirely responsible for Indian school work, allowing the Church to impart religious instruction.

In all the other agencies except yours the old system has almost passed away. The Indian Department has erected fine school buildings and pays good salaries to the Indian school teachers and meets all expenses such as travelling etc.

At Hazelton and Gitwangak the Indian Department still makes use of our Church buildings without allowing anything in the way of rent.

Some time ago I informed Miss Kemp, the Indian day school teacher at Gitwangak that she was to look to the Indian Department entirely for her salary and as a Church we have ceased to have any responsibility in regard to her.

I think that the Department should erect a new school house at Gitwangak and set our school building free for Church Army purposes and also the school children sitting there for so many hours.

Under the old system there was divided authority, Church and State. Under the new system the Indian Department has full control which is far more satisfactory.
There is the Indian Agent, the Inspector of Indian Agencies, and the Indian school inspector,—all looking after these schools.

May I ask you to notify the Department that we require our Church building at Gitwangak for Church Army purposes and that this building is no longer suitable for school purposes.

As I have said in nearly all our other Missions, such as Metlakatla, Kincolith, Lakelsep etc the Department has erected fine new school houses and there is no reason why Gitwangak should not have one also.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd) F.H.B. Vernet
